verses.textLa: Diligit enim gentem nostram: et synagogam ipse ædificavit nobis.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus went with them. And when he was now not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying: “Lord, do not trouble yourself. For I am not worthy that you should enter under my roof.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem ibat cum illis. Et cum iam non longe esset a domo, misit ad eum Centurio amicos, dicens: Domine noli vexari: Non enim sum dignus ut sub tectum meum intres.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I also did not consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant shall be healed.
verses.textLa: Propter quod et meipsum non sum dignum arbitratus ut venirem ad te: sed dic verbo, et sanabitur puer meus.

verses.textEn: For I also am a man placed under authority, having soldiers under me. And I say to one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and to another, ‘Come,’ and he comes; and to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
verses.textLa: nam et ego homo sum sub potestate constitutus, habens sub me milites: et dico huic, Vade, et vadit: et alii, Veni, et venit: et servo meo, Fac hoc, et facit.

verses.textEn: And upon hearing this, Jesus was amazed. And turning to the multitude following him, he said, “Amen I say to you, not even in Israel have I found such great faith.”
verses.textLa: Quo audito Iesus miratus est: et conversus sequentibus se turbis, dixit: Amen dico vobis, nec in Israel tantam fidem inveni.

verses.textEn: And those who had been sent, upon returning to the house, found that the servant, who had been sick, was now healthy.
verses.textLa: Et reversi, qui missi fuerant domum, invenerunt servum, qui languerat, sanum.

verses.textEn: And it happened afterwards that he went to a city, which is called Nain. And his disciples, and an abundant crowd, went with him.
verses.textLa: Et factum est: deinceps ibat in civitatem, quæ vocatur Naim: et ibant cum eo discipuli eius, et turba copiosa.

verses.textEn: Then, when he had drawn near to the gate of the city, behold, a deceased person was being carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow. And a large crowd from the city was with her.
verses.textLa: Cum autem appropinquaret portæ civitatis, ecce defunctus efferebatur filius unicus matris suæ: et hæc vidua erat: et turba civitatis multa cum illa.

verses.textEn: And when the Lord had seen her, being moved by mercy over her, he said to her, “Do not weep.”
verses.textLa: Quam cum vidisset Dominus, misericordia motus super eam, dixit illi: Noli flere.

verses.textEn: And he drew near and touched the coffin. Then those who carried it stood still. And he said, “Young man, I say to you, arise.”
verses.textLa: Et accessit, et tetigit loculum. (Hi autem, qui portabant, steterunt) Et ait: Adolescens, tibi dico, surge.

verses.textEn: And the dead youth sat up and began to speak. And he gave him to his mother.
verses.textLa: Et resedit qui erat mortuus, et cœpit loqui. Et dedit illum matri suæ.

verses.textEn: Then fear fell over all of them. And they magnified God, saying: “For a great prophet has risen up among us,” and, “For God has visited his people.”
verses.textLa: Accepit autem omnes timor: et magnificabant Deum, dicentes: Quia propheta magnus surrexit in nobis: et Quia Deus visitavit plebem suam.

verses.textEn: And this word about him went out to all of Judea and to the entire surrounding region.
verses.textLa: Et exiit hic sermo in universam Iudæam de eo, et in omnem circa regionem.

verses.textEn: And the disciples of John reported to him concerning all these things.
verses.textLa: Et nunciaverunt Ioanni discipuli eius de omnibus his.

verses.textEn: And John called two of his disciples, and he sent them to Jesus, saying, “Are you he who is to come, or should we wait for another?”
verses.textLa: Et convocavit duos de discipulis suis Ioannes, et misit ad Iesum, dicens: Tu es, qui venturus es, an alium expectamus?

verses.textEn: But when the men had come to him, they said: “John the Baptist has sent us to you, saying: ‘Are you he who is to come, or should we wait for another?’ ”
verses.textLa: Cum autem venissent ad eum viri, dixerunt: Ioannes Baptista misit nos ad te dicens: Tu es, qui venturus es, an alium expectamus?

verses.textEn: Now in that same hour, he cured many of their diseases and wounds and evil spirits; and to many of the blind, he gave sight.
verses.textLa: (In ipsa autem hora multos curavit a languoribus, et plagis, et spiritibus malis, et cæcis multis donavit visum.)

verses.textEn: And responding, he said to them: “Go and report to John what you have heard and seen: that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead rise again, the poor are evangelized.
verses.textLa: Et respondens, dixit illis: Euntes renunciate Ioanni quæ audistis, et vidistis: Quia cæci vident, claudi ambulant, leprosi mundantur, surdi audiunt, mortui resurgunt, pauperes evangelizantur:

verses.textEn: And blessed is anyone who has not taken offense at me.”
verses.textLa: et beatus est quicumque non fuerit scandalizatus in me.

verses.textEn: And when the messengers of John had withdrawn, he began to speak about John to the crowds. “What did you go out to the desert to see? A reed shaken by the wind?
verses.textLa: Et cum discessissent nuncii Ioannis, cœpit de Ioanne dicere ad turbas: Quid existis in desertum videre? Arundinem vento agitatam?

verses.textEn: Then what did you go out to see? A man clothed in soft garments? Behold, those who are in costly apparel and finery are in the houses of kings.
verses.textLa: Sed quid existis videre? Hominem mollibus vestibus indutum? Ecce qui in veste pretiosa sunt et deliciis, in domibus regum sunt.

verses.textEn: Then what did you go out to see? A prophet? Certainly, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
verses.textLa: Sed quid existis videre? Prophetam? Utique dico vobis, et plus quam Prophetam:

verses.textEn: This is he of whom it is written: “Behold, I send my Angel before your face, who shall prepare your way before you.”
verses.textLa: Hic est, de quo scriptum est: Ecce mitto Angelum meum ante faciem tuam, qui præparabit viam tuam ante te.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, among those born of women, no one is greater than the prophet John the Baptist. But he who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.”
verses.textLa: Dico enim vobis: Maior inter natos mulierum propheta Ioanne Baptista nemo est. Qui autem minor est in regno Dei, maior est illo.

verses.textEn: And upon hearing this, all the people and the tax collectors justified God, by being baptized with the baptism of John.
verses.textLa: Et omnis populus audiens et publicani, iustificaverunt Deum, baptizati Baptismo Ioannis.

verses.textEn: But the Pharisees and the experts in the law despised the counsel of God concerning themselves, by not being baptized by him.
verses.textLa: Pharisæi autem, et legisperiti consilium Dei spreverunt in semetipsos, non baptizati ab eo.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said: “Therefore, to what shall I compare the men of this generation? And to what are they similar?
verses.textLa: Ait autem Dominus: Cui ergo similes dicam homines generationis huius? et cui similes sunt?

verses.textEn: They are like children sitting in the marketplace, talking with one another, and saying: ‘We sang to you, and you did not dance. We lamented, and you did not weep.’
verses.textLa: Similes sunt pueris sedentibus in foro, et loquentibus ad invicem, et dicentibus: Cantavimus vobis tibiis, et non saltastis: lamentavimus, et non plorastis.

verses.textEn: For John the Baptist came, neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, ‘He has a demon.’
verses.textLa: Venit enim Ioannes Baptista, neque manducans panem, neque bibens vinum, et dicitis: Dæmonium habet.

verses.textEn: The Son of man came, eating and drinking, and you say, ‘Behold, a voracious man and a drinker of wine, a friend of tax collectors and of sinners.’
verses.textLa: Venit Filius hominis manducans, et bibens, et dicitis: Ecce homo devorator, et bibens vinum, amicus publicanorum, et peccatorum.

verses.textEn: But wisdom is justified by all her children.”
verses.textLa: Et iustificata est sapientia ab omnibus filiis suis.

verses.textEn: Then certain Pharisees petitioned him, so that they might eat with him. And he went into the house of the Pharisee, and he reclined at table.
verses.textLa: Rogabat autem illum quidam de Pharisæis ut manducaret cum illo. Et ingressus domum Pharisæi discubuit.

verses.textEn: And behold, a woman who was in the city, a sinner, found out that he was reclining at table in the house of the Pharisee, so she brought an alabaster container of ointment.
verses.textLa: Et ecce mulier, quæ erat in civitate peccatrix, ut cognovit quod accubuisset in domo Pharisæi, attulit alabastrum unguenti:

verses.textEn: And standing behind him, beside his feet, she began to wash his feet with tears, and she wiped them with the hair of her head, and she kissed his feet, and she anointed them with ointment.
verses.textLa: et stans retro secus pedes eius, lacrymis cœpit rigare pedes eius, et capillis capitis sui tergebat, et osculabatur pedes eius, et unguento ungebat.

verses.textEn: Then the Pharisee, who had invited him, upon seeing this, spoke within himself, saying, “This man, if he were a prophet, would certainly know who and what kind of woman is this, who is touching him: that she is a sinner.”
verses.textLa: Videns autem Pharisæus, qui vocaverat eum, ait intra se dicens: Hic si esset propheta, sciret utique, quæ, et qualis est mulier, quæ tangit eum: quia peccatrix est.

verses.textEn: And in response, Jesus said to him, “Simon, I have something to say to you.” So he said, “Speak, Teacher.”
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iesus, dixit ad illum: Simon, habeo tibi aliquid dicere. At ille ait: Magister, dic.

verses.textEn: “A certain creditor had two debtors: one owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
verses.textLa: Duo debitores erant cuidam fœneratori: unus debebat denarios quingentos, et alius quinquaginta.

verses.textEn: And since they did not have the ability to repay him, he forgave them both. So then, which of them loves him more?”
verses.textLa: Non habentibus illis unde redderent, donavit utrisque. Quis ergo eum plus diligit?

verses.textEn: In response, Simon said, “I suppose that it is he to whom he forgave the most.” And he said to him, “You have judged correctly.”
verses.textLa: Respondens Simon dixit: Æstimo quia is, cui plus donavit. At ille dixit ei: Recte iudicasti.

verses.textEn: And turning to the woman, he said to Simon: “Do you see this woman? I entered into your house. You gave me no water for my feet. But she has washed my feet with tears, and has wiped them with her hair.
verses.textLa: Et conversus ad mulierem, dixit Simoni: Vides hanc mulierem? Intravi in domum tuam, aquam pedibus meis non dedisti: hæc autem lacrymis rigavit pedes meos, et capillis suis tersit.

verses.textEn: You gave no kiss to me. But she, from the time that she entered, has not ceased to kiss my feet.
verses.textLa: Osculum mihi non dedisti: hæc autem ex quo intravit, non cessavit osculari pedes meos.

verses.textEn: You did not anoint my head with oil. But she has anointed my feet with ointment.
verses.textLa: Oleo caput meum non unxisti: hæc autem unguento unxit pedes meos.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I tell you: many sins are forgiven her, because she has loved much. But he who is forgiven less, loves less.”
verses.textLa: Propter quod dico tibi: Remittuntur ei peccata multa, quoniam dilexit multum. Cui autem minus dimittitur, minus diligit.

verses.textEn: Then he said to her, “Your sins are forgiven you.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ad illam: Remittuntur tibi peccata.

verses.textEn: And those who sat at table with him began to say within themselves, “Who is this, who even forgives sins?”
verses.textLa: Et cœperunt qui simul accumbebant, dicere intra se: Quis est hic, qui etiam peccata dimittit?

verses.textEn: Then he said to the woman: “Your faith has brought you salvation. Go in peace.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ad mulierem: Fides tua te salvam fecit: vade in pace.

verses.textEn: And it happened afterwards that he was making a journey through the cities and towns, preaching and evangelizing the kingdom of God. And the twelve were with him,
verses.textLa: Et factum est deinceps, et ipse iter faciebat per civitates, et castella prædicans, et evangelizans regnum Dei: et duodecim cum illo,

verses.textEn: along with certain women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities: Mary, who is called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had departed,
verses.textLa: et mulieres aliquæ, quæ erant curatæ a spiritibus malignis, et infirmatibus: Maria, quæ vocatur Magdalene, de qua septem dæmonia exierant,

verses.textEn: and Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod’s steward, and Susanna, and many other women, who were ministering to him from their resources.
verses.textLa: et Ioanna uxor Chusæ procuratoris Herodis, et Susanna, et aliæ multæ, quæ ministrabant ei de facultatibus suis.

verses.textEn: Then, when a very numerous crowd was gathering together and hurrying from the cities to him, he spoke using a comparison:
verses.textLa: Cum autem turba plurima convenirent, et de civitatibus properarent ad eum, dixit per similitudinem:

verses.textEn: “The sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some fell beside the way; and it was trampled and the birds of the air devoured it.
verses.textLa: Exiit qui seminat, seminare semen suum: et dum seminat, aliud cecidit secus viam, et conculcatum est, et volucres cæli comederunt illud.

verses.textEn: And some fell upon rock; and having sprung up, it withered away, because it had no moisture.
verses.textLa: Et aliud cecidit supra petrum: et natum aruit, quia non habebat humorem.

verses.textEn: And some fell among thorns; and the thorns, rising up with it, suffocated it.
verses.textLa: Et aliud cecidit inter spinas, et simul exortæ spinæ suffocaverunt illud.

verses.textEn: And some fell upon good soil; and having sprung up, it produced fruit one hundredfold.” As he said these things, he cried out, “Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”
verses.textLa: Et aliud cecidit in terram bonam: et ortum fecit fructum centuplum. Hæc dicens clamabat: Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.

verses.textEn: Then his disciples questioned him as to what this parable might mean.
verses.textLa: Interrogabant autem eum discipuli eius, quæ esset hæc parabola.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “To you it has been given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God. But to the rest, it is in parables, so that: seeing, they may not perceive, and hearing, they may not understand.
verses.textLa: Quibus ipse dixit: Vobis datum est nosse mysterium regni Dei, ceteris autem in parabolis: ut videntes non videant, et audientes non intelligant.

verses.textEn: Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God.
verses.textLa: Est autem hæc parabola: Semen est verbum Dei.

verses.textEn: And those beside the way are those who hear it, but then the devil comes and takes the word from their heart, lest by believing it they may be saved.
verses.textLa: Qui autem secus viam, hi sunt qui audiunt: deinde venit diabolus, et tollit verbum de corde eorum, ne credentes salvi fiant.

verses.textEn: Now those upon rock are those who, when they hear it, accept the word with joy, but these have no roots. So they believe for a time, but in a time of testing, they fall away.
verses.textLa: Nam qui supra petram: qui cum audierint, cum gaudio suscipiunt verbum: et hi radices non habent: qui ad tempus credunt, et in tempore tentationis recedunt.

verses.textEn: And those which fell among thorns are those who have heard it, but as they go along, they are suffocated by the concerns and riches and pleasures of this life, and so they do not yield fruit.
verses.textLa: Quod autem in spinas cecidit: hi sunt, qui audierunt, et a sollicitudinibus, et divitiis, et voluptatibus vitæ euntes, suffocantur, et non referunt fructum.

verses.textEn: But those which were on good soil are those who, upon hearing the word with a good and noble heart, retain it, and they bring forth fruit in patience.
verses.textLa: Quod autem in bonam terram: hi sunt, qui in corde bono et optimo audientes verbum retinent, et fructum afferunt in patientia.

verses.textEn: Now no one, lighting a candle, covers it with a container, or sets it under a bed. Instead, he places it on a lampstand, so that those who enter may see the light.
verses.textLa: Nemo autem lucernam accendens, operit eam vase, aut subtus lectum ponit: sed supra candelabrum ponit, ut intrantes videant lumen.

verses.textEn: For there is nothing secret, which will not be made clear, nor is there anything hidden, which will not be known and be brought into plain sight.
verses.textLa: Non est enim occultum, quod non manifestetur: nec absconditum, quod non cognoscatur, et in palam veniat.

verses.textEn: Therefore, take care how you listen. For whoever has, it will be given to him; and whoever does not have, even what he thinks he has will be taken away from him.”
verses.textLa: Videte ergo quomodo audiatis? Qui enim habet, dabitur illi: et quicumque non habet, etiam quod putat se habere, auferetur ab illo.

verses.textEn: Then his mother and brothers came to him; but they were not able to go to him because of the crowd.
verses.textLa: Venerunt autem ad illum mater, et fratres eius, et non poterant adire eum præ turba.

verses.textEn: And it was reported to him, “Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you.”
verses.textLa: Et nunciatum est illi: Mater tua, et fratres tui stant foris, volentes te videre.

verses.textEn: And in response, he said to them, “My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God and do it.”
verses.textLa: Qui respondens, dixit ad eos: Mater mea, et fratres mei hi sunt, qui verbum Dei audiunt, et faciunt.

verses.textEn: Now it happened, on a certain day, that he climbed into a little boat with his disciples. And he said to them, “Let us make a crossing over the lake.” And they embarked.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem in una dierum: et ipse ascendit in naviculam, et discipuli eius, et ait ad illos: Transfretemus trans stagnum. Et ascenderunt.

verses.textEn: And as they were sailing, he slept. And a windstorm descended over the lake. And they were taking on water and were in danger.
verses.textLa: Et navigantibus illis, obdormivit, et descendit procella venti in stagnum, et complebantur, et periclitabantur.

verses.textEn: Then, drawing near, they awakened him, saying, “Teacher, we are perishing.” But as he rose up, he rebuked the wind and the raging water, and they ceased. And a tranquility occurred.
verses.textLa: Accedentes autem suscitaverunt eum, dicentes: Præceptor, perimus. At ille surgens, increpavit ventum, et tempestatem aquæ, et cessavit: et facta est tranquillitas.

verses.textEn: Then he said to them, “Where is your faith?” And they, being afraid, were amazed, saying to one another, “Who do you think this is, so that he commands both wind and sea, and they obey him?”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem illis: Ubi est fides vestra? Qui timentes, mirati sunt ad invicem, dicentes: Quis putas hic est, quia et ventis, et mari imperat, et obediunt ei?

verses.textEn: And they sailed to the region of the Gerasenes, which is opposite Galilee.
verses.textLa: Et navigaverunt ad regionem Gerasenorum, quæ est contra Galilæam.

verses.textEn: And when he had gone out to the land, a certain man met him, who had now had a demon for a long time. And he did not wear clothes, nor did he stay in a house, but among the sepulchers.
verses.textLa: Et cum egressus esset ad terram, occurrit illi vir quidam, qui habebat dæmonium iam temporibus multis, et vestimento non induebatur, neque in domo manebat, sed in monumentis.

verses.textEn: And when he saw Jesus, he fell down before him. And crying out in a loud voice, he said: “What is there between me and you, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you not to torture me.”
verses.textLa: Is, ut vidit Iesum, procidit ante illum: et exclamans voce magna, dixit: Quid mihi, et tibi est Iesu Fili Dei Altissimi? obsecro te, ne me torqueas.

verses.textEn: For he was ordering the unclean spirit to depart from the man. For on many occasions, it would seize him, and he was bound with chains and held by fetters. But breaking the chains, he was driven by the demon into deserted places.
verses.textLa: Præcipiebat enim spiritui immundo ut exiret ab homine. Multis enim temporibus arripiebat illum, et vinciebatur catenis, et compedibus custoditus. Et ruptis vinculis agebatur a dæmonio in deserta.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus questioned him, saying, “What is your name?” And he said, “Legion,” because many demons had entered into him.
verses.textLa: Interrogavit autem illum Iesus, dicens: Quod tibi nomen est? At ille dixit: Legio: quia intraverant dæmonia multa in eum.

verses.textEn: And they petitioned him not to order them to go into the abyss.
verses.textLa: Et rogabant illum ne imperaret illis ut in abyssum irent.

verses.textEn: And in that place, there was a herd of many swine, pasturing on the mountain. And they petitioned him to permit them to enter into them. And he permitted them.
verses.textLa: Erat autem ibi grex porcorum multorum pascentium in monte: et rogabant eum, ut permitteret eis in illos ingredi. Et permisit illis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the demons departed from the man, and they entered into the swine. And the herd rushed violently down a precipice into the lake, and they were drowned.
verses.textLa: Exierunt ergo dæmonia ab homine, et intraverunt in porcos: et impetu abiit grex per præceps in stagnum, et suffocatus est.

verses.textEn: And when those who were pasturing them had seen this, they fled and reported it in the city and the villages.
verses.textLa: Quod ut viderunt factum qui pascebant, fugerunt, et nunciaverunt in civitatem, et in villas.

verses.textEn: Then they went out to see what was happening, and they came to Jesus. And they found the man, from whom the demons had departed, sitting at his feet, clothed as well as in a sane mind, and they were afraid.
verses.textLa: Exierunt autem videre quod factum est, et venerunt ad Iesum: et invenerunt hominem sedentem, a quo dæmonia exierant, vestitum ac sana mente ad pedes eius, et timuerunt.

verses.textEn: Then those who had seen this also reported to them how he had been healed from the legion.
verses.textLa: Nunciaverunt autem illis et qui viderant, quomodo sanus factus esset a legione:

verses.textEn: And the entire multitude from the region of the Gerasenes pleaded with him to depart from them. For they were seized by a great fear. Then, climbing into the boat, he went back again.
verses.textLa: et rogaverunt illum omnis multitudo regionis Gerasenorum ut discederet ab ipsis: quia magno timore tenebantur. Ipse autem ascendens navim, reversus est.

verses.textEn: And the man from whom the demons had departed pleaded with him, so that he might be with him. But Jesus sent him away, saying,
verses.textLa: Et rogabat illum vir, a quo dæmonia exierant, ut cum eo esset. Dimisit autem eum Iesus, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Return to your house and explain to them what great things God has done for you.” And he traveled through the entire city, preaching about the great things that Jesus had done for him.
verses.textLa: Redi in domum tuam, et narra quanta tibi fecit Deus. Et abiit per universam civitatem, prædicans quanta illi fecisset Iesus.

verses.textEn: Now it happened that, when Jesus had returned, the crowd received him. For they were all waiting for him.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem cum rediisset Iesus, excepit illum turba. Erunt enim omnes expectantes eum.

verses.textEn: And behold, a man came, whose name was Jairus, and he was a leader of the synagogue. And he fell down at the feet of Jesus, asking him to enter into his house.
verses.textLa: Et ecce venit vir, cui nomen Iairus, et ipse princeps synagogæ erat: et cecidit ad pedes Iesu, rogans eum ut intraret in domum eius,

verses.textEn: For he had an only daughter, nearly twelve years old, and she was dying. And it happened that, as he was going there, he was hemmed in by the crowd.
verses.textLa: quia unica filia erat ei fere annorum duodecim, et hæc moriebatur. Et contigit, dum iret, a turba comprimebatur.

verses.textEn: And there was a certain woman, with a flow of blood for twelve years, who had paid out all her substance on physicians, and she was unable to be cured by any of them.
verses.textLa: Et mulier quædam erat in fluxu sanguinis ab annis duodecim, quæ in medicos erogaverat omnem substantiam suam, nec ab ullo potuit curari:

verses.textEn: She approached him from behind, and she touched the hem of his garment. And at once the flow of her blood stopped.
verses.textLa: accessit retro, et tetigit fimbriam vestimenti eius: et confestim stetit fluxus sanguinis eius.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said, “Who is it that touched me?” But as everyone was denying it, Peter, and those who were with him, said: “Teacher, the crowd hems you in and presses upon you, and yet you say, ‘Who touched me?’ ”
verses.textLa: Et ait Iesus: Quis est, qui me tetigit? Negantibus autem omnibus, dixit Petrus, et qui cum illo erant: Præceptor, turbæ te comprimunt, et affligunt, et dicis: Quis me tetigit?

verses.textEn: And Jesus said: “Someone has touched me. For I know that power has gone out from me.”
verses.textLa: Et dicit Iesus: Tetigit me aliquis. Nam ego novi virtutem de me exiisse.

verses.textEn: Then the woman, upon seeing that she was not hidden, came forward, trembling, and she fell down before his feet. And she declared before all the people the reason that she had touched him, and how she had been immediately healed.
verses.textLa: Videns autem mulier, quia non latuit, tremens venit, et procidit ante pedes eius: et ob quam causam tetigerit eum, indicavit coram omni populo: et quemadmodum confestim sanata sit.

verses.textEn: But he said to her: “Daughter, your faith has saved you. Go in peace.”
verses.textLa: At ipse dixit ei: Filia, fides tua salvam te fecit: vade in pace.

verses.textEn: While he was still speaking, someone came to the ruler of the synagogue, saying to him: “Your daughter is dead. Do not trouble him.”
verses.textLa: Adhuc illo loquente, venit quidam ad principem synagogæ, dicens ei: Quia mortua est filia tua, noli vexare illum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, upon hearing this word, replied to the father of the girl: “Do not be afraid. Only believe, and she will be saved.”
verses.textLa: Iesus autem, audito hoc verbo, respondit patri puellæ: Noli timere, crede tantum, et salva erit.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the house, he would not permit anyone to enter with him, except Peter and James and John, and the father and mother of the girl.
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset domum, non permisit intrare secum quemquam, nisi Petrum, et Iacobum, et Ioannem, et patrem, et matrem puellæ.

verses.textEn: Now all were weeping and mourning for her. But he said: “Do not weep. The girl is not dead, but only sleeping.”
verses.textLa: Flebant autem omnes, et plangebant illam. At ille dixit: Nolite flere, non est mortua puella, sed dormit.

verses.textEn: And they derided him, knowing that she had died.
verses.textLa: Et deridebant eum, scientes quod mortua esset.

verses.textEn: But he, taking her by the hand, cried out, saying, “Little girl, arise.”
verses.textLa: Ipse autem tenens manum eius clamavit, dicens: Puella, surge.

verses.textEn: And her spirit returned, and she immediately rose up. And he ordered them to give her something to eat.
verses.textLa: Et reversus est spiritus eius, et surrexit continuo. Et iussit illi dari manducare.

verses.textEn: And her parents were stupefied. And he instructed them not to tell anyone what had happened.
verses.textLa: Et stupuerunt parentes eius, quibus præcepit ne alicui dicerent quod factum erat.

verses.textEn: Then calling together the twelve Apostles, he gave them power and authority over all demons and to cure diseases.
verses.textLa: Convocatis autem duodecim Apostolis, dedit illis virtutem, et potestatem super omnia dæmonia, et ut languores curarent.

verses.textEn: And he sent them to preach the kingdom of God and to heal the infirm.
verses.textLa: Et misit illos prædicare regnum Dei, et sanare infirmos.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “You should take nothing for the journey, neither staff, nor traveling bag, nor bread, nor money; and you should not have two tunics.
verses.textLa: Et ait ad illos: Nihil tuleritis in via, neque virgam, neque peram, neque panem, neque pecuniam, neque duas tunicas habeatis.

verses.textEn: And into whatever house you shall enter, lodge there, and do not move away from there.
verses.textLa: Et in quamcumque domum intraveritis, ibi manete, et inde ne exeatis.

verses.textEn: And whoever will not have received you, upon departing from that city, shake off even the dust on your feet, as a testimony against them.”
verses.textLa: Et quicumque non receperint vos: exeuntes de civitate illa, etiam pulverem pedum vestrorum excutite in testimonium supra illos.

verses.textEn: And going forth, they traveled around, through the towns, evangelizing and curing everywhere.
verses.textLa: Egressi autem circuibant per castella evangelizantes, et curantes ubique.

verses.textEn: Now Herod the tetrarch heard about all the things that were being done by him, but he doubted, because it was said
verses.textLa: Audivit autem Herodes tetrarcha omnia, quæ fiebant ab eo, et hæsitabat eo quod diceretur

verses.textEn: by some, “For John has risen from the dead,” yet truly, by others, “For Elijah has appeared,” and by still others, “For one of the prophets from of old has risen again.”
verses.textLa: a quibusdam: Quia Ioannes surrexit a mortuis: a quibusdam vero: Quia Elias apparuit: ab aliis autem: Quia propheta unus de antiquis surrexit.

verses.textEn: And Herod said: “I beheaded John. So then, who is this, about whom I hear such things?” And he sought to see him.
verses.textLa: Et ait Herodes: Ioannem ego decollavit: Quis est autem iste, de quo ego talia audio? Et quærebat videre eum.

verses.textEn: And when the Apostles returned, they explained to him all the things that they had done. And taking them with him, he withdrew to a deserted place apart, which belongs to Bethsaida.
verses.textLa: Et reversi Apostoli, narraverunt illi quæcumque fecerunt: et assumptis illis secessit seorsum in locum desertum, qui est Bethsaidæ.

verses.textEn: But when the crowd had realized this, they followed him. And he received them and spoke to them about the kingdom of God. And those who were in need of cures, he healed.
verses.textLa: Quod cum cognovissent turbæ, secutæ sunt illum: et excepit eos, et loquebatur illis de regno Dei, et eos, qui cura indigebant, sanabat.

verses.textEn: Then the day began to decline. And drawing near, the twelve said to him: “Dismiss the crowds, so that, by going into the surrounding towns and villages, they may separate and find food. For we are here in a deserted place.”
verses.textLa: Dies autem cœperat declinare. Et accedentes duodecim dixerunt illi: Dimitte turbas, ut euntes in castella, villasque quæ circa sunt, divertant, et inveniant escas: quia hic in loco deserto sumus.

verses.textEn: But he said to them, “You give them something to eat.” And they said, “There is with us no more than five loaves and two fish, unless perhaps we are to go and buy food for this entire multitude.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem ad illos: Vos date illis manducare. At illi dixerunt: Non sunt nobis plus quam quinque panes, et duo pisces: nisi forte nos eamus, et emamus in omnem hanc turbam escas.

verses.textEn: Now there were about five thousand men. So he said to his disciples, “Have them recline to eat in groups of fifty.”
verses.textLa: Erant autem fere viri quinque millia. Ait autem ad discipulos suos: Facite illos discumbere per convivia quinquagenos.

verses.textEn: And they did so. And they caused them all to recline to eat.
verses.textLa: Et ita fecerunt. Et discumbere fecerunt omnes.

verses.textEn: Then, taking the five loaves and the two fish, he gazed up to heaven, and he blessed and broke and distributed them to his disciples, in order to set them before the crowd.
verses.textLa: Acceptis autem quinque panibus, et duobus piscibus, respexit in cælum: et benedixit illis, et fregit, et distribuit discipulis suis, ut ponerent ante turbas.

verses.textEn: And they all ate and were satisfied. And twelve baskets of fragments were taken up, which were left over from them.
verses.textLa: Et manducaverunt omnes, et saturati sunt. Et sublatum est quod superfuit illis, fragmentorum cophini duodecim.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when he was praying alone, his disciples also were with him, and he questioned them, saying: “Who do the multitudes say that I am?”
verses.textLa: Et factum est cum solus esset orans, erant cum illo et discipuli: et interrogavit illos, dicens: Quem me dicunt esse turbæ?
verses.notes: The word ‘who’ is used here instead of the more grammatically correct ‘whom’ because in conversation, people generally use ‘who’ instead of ‘whom’ in this type of sentence.

verses.textEn: But they answered by saying: “John the Baptist. But some say Elijah. Yet truly, others say that one of the prophets from before has risen again.”
verses.textLa: At illi responderunt, et dixerunt: Ioannem Baptistam, alii autem Eliam, alii vero quia unus Propheta de prioribus surrexit.

verses.textEn: Then he said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” In response, Simon Peter said, “The Christ of God.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem illis: Vos autem quem me esse dicitis? Respondens Simon Petrus dixit: Christum Dei.

verses.textEn: But speaking sharply to them, he instructed them not to tell this to anyone,
verses.textLa: At ille increpans illos, præcepit ne cui dicerent hoc,

verses.textEn: saying, “For the Son of man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and the leaders of the priests and the scribes, and be killed, and on the third day rise again.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Quia oportet Filium hominis multa pati, et reprobari a senioribus, et principibus sacerdotum, et scribis, et occidi, et tertia die resurgere.

verses.textEn: Then he said to everyone: “If anyone is willing to come after me: let him deny himself, and take up his cross every day, and follow me.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem ad omnes: Si quis vult post me venire, abneget semetipsum, et tollat crucem suam quotidie, et sequatur me.

verses.textEn: For whoever will have saved his life, will lose it. Yet whoever will have lost his life for my sake, will save it.
verses.textLa: Qui enim voluerit animam suam salvam facere, perdet illam: nam qui perdiderit animam suam propter me, salvam faciet illam.

verses.textEn: For how does it benefit a man, if he were to gain the whole world, yet lose himself, or cause himself harm?
verses.textLa: Quid enim proficit homo, si lucretur universum mundum, se autem ipsum perdat, et detrimentum sui faciat?

verses.textEn: For whoever will be ashamed of me and of my words: of him the Son of man will be ashamed, when he will have arrived in his majesty and that of his Father and of the holy Angels.
verses.textLa: Nam qui me erubuerit, et meos sermones: hunc Filius hominis erubescet cum venerit in maiestate sua, et Patris, et sanctorum Angelorum.

verses.textEn: And yet, I tell you a truth: There are some standing here who shall not taste death, until they see the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis vere: sunt aliqui hic stantes, qui non gustabunt mortem donec videant regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, about eight days after these words, he took Peter and James and John, and he ascended onto a mountain, so that he might pray.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem post hæc verba fere dies octo, et assumpsit Petrum, et Iacobum, et Ioannem, et ascendit in montem ut oraret.

verses.textEn: And while he was praying, the appearance of his countenance was altered, and his vestment became white and shining.
verses.textLa: Et facta est, dum oraret, species vultus eius altera: et vestitus eius albus et refulgens.

verses.textEn: And behold, two men were talking with him. And these were Moses and Elijah, appearing in majesty.
verses.textLa: Et ecce duo viri loquebantur cum illo. Erant autem Moyses, et Elias, visi in maiestate:

verses.textEn: And they spoke of his departure, which he would accomplish at Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: et dicebant excessum eius, quem completurus erat in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Peter and those who were with him were weighed down by sleep. And becoming alert, they saw his majesty and the two men who were standing with him.
verses.textLa: Petrus vero, et qui cum illo erant, gravati erant somno. Et evigilantes viderunt maiestatem eius, et duos viros, qui stabant cum illo.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, as these were departing from him, Peter said to Jesus: “Teacher, it is good for us to be here. And so, let us make three tabernacles: one for you, and one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” For he did not know what he was saying.
verses.textLa: Et factum est cum discederent ab illo, ait Petrus ad Iesum: Præceptor, bonum est nos hic esse: et faciamus tria tabernacula, unum Tibi, et unum Moysi, et unum Eliæ: nesciens quid diceret.

verses.textEn: Then, as he was saying these things, a cloud came and overshadowed them. And as these were entering into the cloud, they were afraid.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem illo loquente, facta est nubes, et obumbravit eos: et timuerunt, intrantibus illis in nubem.

verses.textEn: And a voice came from the cloud, saying: “This is my beloved Son. Listen to him.”
verses.textLa: Et vox facta est de nube, dicens: Hic est Filius meus dilectus, ipsum audite.

verses.textEn: And while the voice was being uttered, Jesus was found to be alone. And they were silent and told no one, in those days, any of these things, which they had seen.
verses.textLa: Et dum fieret vox, inventus est Iesus solus. Et ipsi tacuerunt, et nemini dixerunt in illis diebus quidquam ex his, quæ viderant.

verses.textEn: But it happened on the following day that, as they were descending from the mountain, a great crowd met him.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem in sequenti die, descendentibus illis de monte, occurrit illis turba multa.

verses.textEn: And behold, a man from the crowd cried out, saying, “Teacher, I beg you, look kindly on my son, for he is my only son.
verses.textLa: Et ecce vir de turba exclamavit, dicens: Magister, obsecro te, respice in filium meum quia unicus est mihi:

verses.textEn: And behold, a spirit takes hold of him, and he suddenly cries out, and it throws him down and convulses him, so that he foams. And though it tears him apart, it leaves him only with difficulty.
verses.textLa: et ecce spiritus apprehendit eum, et subito clamat, et elidit, et dissipat eum cum spuma, et vix discedit dilanians eum:

verses.textEn: And I asked your disciples to cast him out, and they were unable.”
verses.textLa: et rogavi discipulos tuos ut eiicerent illum, et non potuerunt.

verses.textEn: And in response, Jesus said: “O unfaithful and perverse generation! How long will I be with you and endure you? Bring your son here.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit: O generatio infidelis, et perversa, usquequo ero apud vos, et patiar vos? Adduc huc filium tuum.

verses.textEn: And as he was approaching him, the demon threw him down and convulsed him.
verses.textLa: Et cum accederet, elisit illum dæmonium, et dissipavit.

verses.textEn: And Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit, and he healed the boy, and he restored him to his father.
verses.textLa: Et increpavit Iesus spiritum immundum, et sanavit puerum, et reddidit illum patri eius.

verses.textEn: And all were astonished at the greatness of God. And as everyone was wondering over all that he was doing, he said to his disciples: “You must set these words in your hearts. For it shall be that the Son of man will be delivered into the hands of men.”
verses.textLa: Stupebant autem omnes in magnitudine Dei: omnibusque mirantibus in omnibus, quæ faciebat, dixit ad discipulos suos: Ponite vos in cordibus vestris sermones istos: Filius enim hominis futurum est ut tradatur in manus hominum.

verses.textEn: But they did not understand this word, and it was concealed from them, so that they did not perceive it. And they were afraid to question him about this word.
verses.textLa: At illi ignorabant verbum istud, et erat velatum ante eos ut non sentirent illud: et timebant eum interrogare de hoc verbo.

verses.textEn: Now an idea entered into them, as to which of them was greater.
verses.textLa: Intravit autem cogitatio in eos, quis eorum maior esset.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, perceiving the thoughts of their hearts, took a child and stood him beside him.
verses.textLa: At Iesus videns cogitationes cordis illorum, apprehendit puerum, et statuit illum secus se,

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Whoever will receive this child in my name, receives me; and whoever receives me, receives him who sent me. For whoever is the lesser among you all, the same is greater.”
verses.textLa: et ait illis: Quicumque susceperit puerum istum in nomine meo, me recipit: et quicumque me receperit, recipit eum, qui me misit. Nam qui minor est inter vos omnes, hic maior est.

verses.textEn: And responding, John said: “Teacher, we saw a certain one casting out demons in your name. And we prohibited him, for he does not follow with us.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Ioannes dixit: Præceptor, vidimus quemdam in nomine tuo eiicientem dæmonia, et prohibuimus eum: quia non sequitur nobiscum.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to him: “Do not prohibit him. For whoever is not against you, is for you.”
verses.textLa: Et ait ad illum Iesus: Nolite prohibere: qui enim non est adversum vos, pro vobis est.

verses.textEn: Now it happened that, while the days of his dissipation were being completed, he steadfastly set his face to go to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem dum complerentur dies assumptionis eius, et ipse faciem suam firmavit ut iret in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And he sent messengers before his face. And going on, they entered into a city of the Samaritans, to prepare for him.
verses.textLa: Et misit nuncios ante conspectum suum: et euntes intraverunt in civitatem Samaritanorum ut parerent illi.

verses.textEn: And they would not receive him, because his face was going toward Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et non receperunt eum, quia facies eius erat euntis in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And when his disciples, James and John, had seen this, they said, “Lord, do you want us to call for fire to descend from heaven and consume them?”
verses.textLa: Cum vidissent autem discipuli eius Iacobus, et Ioannes, dixerunt: Domine, vis dicimus ut ignis descendat de cælo, et consumat illos?

verses.textEn: And turning, he rebuked them, saying: “Do you not know of whose spirit you are?
verses.textLa: Et conversus increpavit illos, dicens: Nescitis cuius spiritus estis?

verses.textEn: The Son of man came, not to destroy lives, but to save them.” And they went into another town.
verses.textLa: Filius hominis non venit animas perdere, sed salvare. Et abierunt in aliud castellum.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, as they were walking along the way, someone said to him, “I will follow you, wherever you will go.”
verses.textLa: Factum est autem: ambulantibus illis in via, dixit quidam ad illum: Sequar te quocumque ieris.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “Foxes have dens, and the birds of the air have nests. But the Son of man has nowhere to lay his head.”
verses.textLa: Dixit illi Iesus: Vulpes foveas habent, et volucres cæli nidos: Filius autem hominis non habet ubi caput reclinet.

verses.textEn: Then he said to another, “Follow me.” But he said, “Lord, permit me first to go and bury my father.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem ad alterum: Sequere me. Ille autem dixit: Domine permitte mihi primum ire, et sepelire patrem meum.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to him: “Let the dead bury their dead. But you go and announce the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei Iesus: Sine ut mortui sepeliant mortuos suos: tu autem vade, et annuncia regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: And another said: “I will follow you, Lord. But permit me first to explain this to those of my house.”
verses.textLa: Et ait alter: Sequar te Domine, sed permitte mihi primum renunciare his, quæ domi sunt.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him, “No one who puts his hand to the plow, and then looks back, is fit for the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Ait ad illum Iesus: Nemo mittens manum suam ad aratrum, et respiciens retro, aptus est regno Dei.

verses.textEn: Then, after these things, the Lord also designated another seventy-two. And he sent them in pairs before his face, into every city and place where he was to arrive.
verses.textLa: Post hæc autem designavit Dominus et alios septuaginta duos. Et misit illos binos ante faciem suam in omnem civitatem, et locum, quo erat ipse venturus.
verses.notes: Notice the different wording used for the 72 as compared to the 12. The 12 were appointed, but the 72 were designated, indicating different roles. The 12 were Apostles, but the 72 were more like deacons.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Certainly the harvest is great, but the workers are few. Therefore, ask the Lord of the harvest to send workers into his harvest.
verses.textLa: Et dicebat illis: Messis quidem multa, operarii autem pauci. Rogate ergo Dominum messis ut mittat operarios in messem suam.

verses.textEn: Go forth. Behold, I send you out like lambs among wolves.
verses.textLa: Ite: ecce ego mitto vos sicut agnos inter lupos.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to carry a purse, nor provisions, nor shoes; and you shall greet no one along the way.
verses.textLa: Nolite portare sacculum, neque peram, neque calceamenta, et neminem per viam salutaveritis.

verses.textEn: Into whatever house you will have entered, first say, ‘Peace to this house.’
verses.textLa: In quamcumque domum intraveritis, primum dicite: Pax huic domui:

verses.textEn: And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him. But if not, it will return to you.
verses.textLa: et si ibi fuerit filius pacis, requiescet super illum pax vestra: sin autem, ad vos revertetur.

verses.textEn: And remain in the same house, eating and drinking the things that are with them. For the worker is worthy of his pay. Do not choose to pass from house to house.
verses.textLa: In eadem autem domo manete edentes, et bibentes quæ apud illos sunt: dignus est enim operarius mercede sua. Nolite transire de domo in domum.

verses.textEn: And into whatever city you have entered and they have received you, eat what they set before you.
verses.textLa: Et in quamcumque civitatem intraveritis, et susceperint vos, manducate quæ apponuntur vobis:

verses.textEn: And cure the sick who are in that place, and proclaim to them, ‘The kingdom of God has drawn near to you.’
verses.textLa: et curate infirmos, qui in illa sunt, et dicite illis: Appropinquavit in vos regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: But into whatever city you have entered and they have not received you, going out into its main streets, say:
verses.textLa: In quamcumque autem civitatem intraveritis, et non susceperint vos, exeuntes in plateas eius, dicite:

verses.textEn: ‘Even the dust which clings to us from your city, we wipe away against you. Yet know this: the kingdom of God has drawn near.’
verses.textLa: Etiam pulverem, qui adhæsit nobis de civitate vestra, extergimus in vos: tamen hoc scitote, quia appropinquavit regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: I say to you, that in that day, Sodom will be forgiven more than that city will be.
verses.textLa: Dico vobis, quia Sodomis in die illa remissius erit, quam illi civitati.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that have been wrought in you, had been wrought in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in haircloth and ashes.
verses.textLa: Væ tibi Corozain, væ tibi Bethsaida: quia si in Tyro, et Sidone factæ fuissent virtutes, quæ factæ sunt in vobis, olim in cilicio, et cinere sedentes pœniterent.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Tyre and Sidon will be forgiven more in the judgment than you will be.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen Tyro, et Sidoni remissius erit in iudicio, quam vobis.

verses.textEn: And as for you, Capernaum, who would be exalted even up to Heaven: you shall be submerged into Hell.
verses.textLa: Et tu Capharnaum usque ad cælum exaltata, usque ad infernum demergeris.

verses.textEn: Whoever hears you, hears me. And whoever despises you, despises me. And whoever despises me, despises him who sent me.”
verses.textLa: Qui vos audit, me audit: et qui vos spernit, me spernit. Qui autem me spernit, spernit eum, qui misit me.

verses.textEn: Then the seventy-two returned with gladness, saying, “Lord, even the demons are subject to us, in your name.”
verses.textLa: Reversi sunt autem septuaginta duo cum gaudio, dicentes: Domine, etiam dæmonia subiiciuntur nobis in nomine tuo.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “I was watching as Satan fell like lightning from heaven.
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Videbam Satanam sicut fulgor de cælo cadentem.

verses.textEn: Behold, I have given you authority to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and upon all the powers of the enemy, and nothing shall hurt you.
verses.textLa: Ecce dedi vobis potestatem calcandi supra serpentes, et scorpiones, et super omnem virtutem inimici: et nihil vobis nocebit.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, do not choose to rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you; but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”
verses.textLa: Verumtamen in hoc nolite gaudere quia spiritus vobis subiiciuntur: gaudete autem, quod nomina vestra scripta sunt in cælis.

verses.textEn: In the same hour, he exulted in the Holy Spirit, and he said: “I confess to you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and the prudent, and have revealed them to little ones. It is so, Father, because this way was pleasing before you.
verses.textLa: In ipsa hora exultavit Spiritu Sancto, et dixit: Confiteor tibi Pater, Domine cæli et terræ, quod abscondisti hæc a sapientibus, et prudentibus, et revelasti ea parvulis. Etiam Pater: quoniam sic placuit ante te.

verses.textEn: All things have been delivered to me by my Father. And no one knows who the Son is, except the Father, and who the Father is, except the Son, and those to whom the Son has chosen to reveal him.”
verses.textLa: Omnia mihi tradita sunt a Patre meo. Et nemo scit quis sit Filius, nisi Pater: et quis sit Pater, nisi Filius, et cui voluerit Filius revelare.
verses.notes: Since no one can know the Father, except those to whom the Son has chosen to reveal him, the Holy Spirit must proceed from both the Father and the Son, not from the Father alone.

verses.textEn: And turning to his disciples, he said: “Blessed are the eyes that see what you see.
verses.textLa: Et conversus ad discipulos suos, dixit: Beati oculi, qui vident quæ vos videtis.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, that many prophets and kings wanted to see the things that you see, and they did not see them, and to hear the things that you hear, and they did not hear them.”
verses.textLa: Dico enim vobis, quod multi prophetæ, et reges voluerunt videre quæ vos videtis, et non viderunt: et audire quæ auditis, et non audierunt.

verses.textEn: And behold, a certain expert in the law rose up, testing him and saying, “Teacher, what must I do to possess eternal life?”
verses.textLa: Et ecce quidam legis peritus surrexit tentans illum, et dicens: Magister, quid faciendo vitam æternam possidebo?

verses.textEn: But he said to him: “What is written in the law? How do you read it?”
verses.textLa: At ille dixit ad eum: In lege quid scriptum est? Quomodo legis?

verses.textEn: In response, he said: “You shall love the Lord your God from your whole heart, and from your whole soul, and from all your strength, and from all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself.”
verses.textLa: Ille respondens dixit: Diliges Dominum Deum tuum ex toto corde tuo, et ex tota anima tua, et ex omnibus virtutibus tuis, et ex omni mente tua: et proximum tuum sicut teipsum.

verses.textEn: And he said to him: “You have answered correctly. Do this, and you will live.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque illi: Recte respondisti: hoc fac, et vives.

verses.textEn: But since he wanted to justify himself, he said to Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”
verses.textLa: Ille autem volens iustificare seipsum, dixit ad Iesum: Et quis est meus proximus?

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, taking this up, said: “A certain man descended from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he happened upon robbers, who now also plundered him. And inflicting him with wounds, they went away, leaving him behind, half-alive.
verses.textLa: Suscipiens autem Iesus, dixit: Homo quidam descendebat ab Ierusalem in Iericho, et incidit in latrones, qui etiam despoliaverunt eum: et plagis impositis abierunt semivivo relicto.

verses.textEn: And it happened that a certain priest was descending along the same way. And seeing him, he passed by.
verses.textLa: Accidit autem ut sacerdos quidam descenderet eadem via: et viso illo præterivit.

verses.textEn: And similarly a Levite, when he was near the place, also saw him, and he passed by.
verses.textLa: Similiter et Levita, cum esset secus locum, et videret eum, pertransiit.

verses.textEn: But a certain Samaritan, being on a journey, came near him. And seeing him, he was moved by mercy.
verses.textLa: Samaritanus autem quidam iter faciens, venit secus eum: et videns eum, misericordia motus est.

verses.textEn: And approaching him, he bound up his wounds, pouring oil and wine on them. And setting him on his pack animal, he brought him to an inn, and he took care of him.
verses.textLa: Et appropians alligavit vulnera eius, infundens oleum, et vinum: et imponens illum in iumentum suum, duxit in stabulum, et curam eius egit.
verses.notes: A ‘jumentum’ is not just any animal or cattle, but typically one used for carrying loads, hence a pack animal or a beast of burden.

verses.textEn: And the next day, he took out two denarii, and he gave them to the proprietor, and he said: ‘Take care of him. And whatever extra you will have spent, I will repay to you at my return.’
verses.textLa: Et altera die protulit duos denarios, et dedit stabulario, et ait: Curam illius habe: et quodcumque supererogaveris, ego cum rediero reddam tibi.

verses.textEn: Which of these three, does it seem to you, was a neighbor to him who fell among the robbers?”
verses.textLa: Quis horum trium videtur tibi proximus fuisse illi, qui incidit in latrones?

verses.textEn: Then he said, “The one who acted with mercy toward him.” And Jesus said to him, “Go, and act similarly.”
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Qui fecit misericordiam in illum. Et ait illi Iesus: Vade, et tu fac similiter.

verses.textEn: Now it happened that, while they were traveling, he entered into a certain town. And a certain woman, named Martha, received him into her home.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, dum irent, et ipse intravit in quoddam castellum: et mulier quædam Martha nomine, excepit illum in domum suam,

verses.textEn: And she had a sister, named Mary, who, while sitting beside the Lord’s feet, was listening to his word.
verses.textLa: et huic erat soror nomine Maria, quæ etiam sedens secus pedes Domini, audiebat verbum illius.

verses.textEn: Now Martha was continually busying herself with serving. And she stood still and said: “Lord, is it not a concern to you that my sister has left me to serve alone? Therefore, speak to her, so that she may help me.”
verses.textLa: Martha autem satagebat circa frequens ministerium: quæ stetit, et ait: Domine, non est tibi curæ quod soror mea reliquit me solam ministrare? dic ergo illi, ut me adiuvet.

verses.textEn: And the Lord responded by saying to her: “Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled over many things.
verses.textLa: Et respondens dixit illis Dominus: Martha, Martha, sollicita es, et turbaris erga plurima.

verses.textEn: And yet only one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the best portion, and it shall not be taken away from her.”
verses.textLa: Porro unum est necessarium. Maria optimam partem elegit, quæ non auferetur ab ea.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while he was in a certain place praying, when he ceased, one of his disciples said to him, “Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples.”
verses.textLa: Et factum est: cum esset in quodam loco orans, ut cessavit, dixit unus ex discipulis eius ad eum: Domine, doce nos orare, sicut docuit et Ioannes discipulos suos.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “When you are praying, say: Father, may your name be kept holy. May your kingdom come.
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Cum oratis, dicite: Pater, sanctificetur nomen tuum. Adveniat regnum tuum.

verses.textEn: Give us this day our daily bread.
verses.textLa: Panem nostrum quotidianum da nobis hodie.

verses.textEn: And forgive us our sins, since we also forgive all who are indebted to us. And lead us not into temptation.”
verses.textLa: Et dimitte nobis peccata nostra, siquidem et ipsi dimittimus omni debenti nobis. Et ne nos inducas in tentationem.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Which of you will have a friend and will go to him in the middle of the night, and will say to him: ‘Friend, lend me three loaves,
verses.textLa: Et ait ad illos: Quis vestrum habebit amicum, et ibit ad illum media nocte, et dicet illi: Amice, commoda mihi tres panes,

verses.textEn: because a friend of mine has arrived from a journey to me, and I do not have anything to set before him.’
verses.textLa: quoniam amicus meus venit de via ad me, et non habeo quod ponam ante illum.

verses.textEn: And from within, he would answer by saying: ‘Do not disturb me. The door is closed now, and my children and I are in bed. I cannot get up and give it to you.’
verses.textLa: Et ille de intus respondens dicat: Noli mihi molestus esse, iam ostrium clausum est, et pueri mei mecum sunt in cubili: non possum surgere, et dare tibi.

verses.textEn: Yet if he will persevere in knocking, I tell you that, even though he would not get up and give it to him because he is a friend, yet due to his continued insistence, he will get up and give him whatever he needs.
verses.textLa: Et si ille perseveraverit pulsans: dico vobis, etsi non dabit illi surgens eo quod amicus eius sit, propter improbitatem tamen eius surget, et dabit illi quotquot habet necessarios.

verses.textEn: And so I say to you: Ask, and it shall be given to you. Seek, and you shall find. Knock, and it shall be opened to you.
verses.textLa: Et ego dico vobis: Petite, et dabitur vobis; quærite, et invenietis; pulsate, et aperietur vobis.

verses.textEn: For everyone who asks, receives. And whoever seeks, finds. And whoever knocks, it shall be opened to him.
verses.textLa: Omnis enim qui petit, accipit: et qui quærit, invenit: et pulsanti aperietur.

verses.textEn: So then, who among you, if he asks his father for bread, he would give him a stone? Or if he asks for a fish, he would give him a serpent, instead of a fish?
verses.textLa: Quis autem ex vobis patrem petit panem, numquid lapidem dabit illi? Aut piscem: numquid pro pisce serpentem dabit illi?

verses.textEn: Or if he will ask for an egg, he would offer to him a scorpion?
verses.textLa: Aut si petierit ovum: numquid porriget illi scorpionem?

verses.textEn: Therefore, if you, being evil, know how to give good things to your sons, how much more will your Father give, from heaven, a spirit of goodness to those who ask him?”
verses.textLa: Si ergo vos cum sitis mali, nostis bona data dare filiis vestris: quanto magis Pater vester de cælo dabit spiritum bonum petentibus se?
verses.notes: The wording is not ‘Father from heaven’ because the Father is not ‘from’ anything or anywhere; the Father is First. Also, the wording ‘spiritum bonum’ is not the same as the wording ‘Spiritu Sancto’ referring to the Holy Spirit, so it does not refer specifically to the Holy Spirit. Instead, it refers to a gift of the Holy Spirit, to have a spirit or attitude of doing good.

verses.textEn: And he was casting out a demon, and the man was mute. But when he had cast out the demon, the mute man spoke, and so the crowds were amazed.
verses.textLa: Et erat eiiciens dæmonium, et illud erat mutum. Et cum eiecisset dæmonium, locutus est mutus, et admiratæ sunt turbæ.

verses.textEn: But some of them said, “It is by Beelzebub, the leader of demons, that he casts out demons.”
verses.textLa: Quidam autem ex eis dixerunt: In Beelzebub principe dæmoniorum eiicit dæmonia.

verses.textEn: And others, testing him, required a sign from heaven of him.
verses.textLa: Et alii tentantes, signum de cælo quærebant ab eo.

verses.textEn: But when he perceived their thoughts, he said to them: “Every kingdom divided against itself will become desolate, and house will fall upon house.
verses.textLa: Ipse autem ut vidit cogitationes eorum, dixit eis: Omne regnum in seipsum divisum desolabitur, et domus supra domum cadet.

verses.textEn: So then, if Satan is also divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? For you say that it is by Beelzebub that I cast out demons.
verses.textLa: Si autem et Satanas in seipsum divisus est, quomodo stabit regnum eius? quia dicitis in Beelzebub me eiicere dæmonia.

verses.textEn: But if I cast out demons by Beelzebub, by whom do your own sons cast them out? Therefore, they shall be your judges.
verses.textLa: Si autem ego in Beelzebub eiicio dæmonia: filii vestri in quo eiiciunt? Ideo ipsi iudices vestri erunt.

verses.textEn: Moreover, if it is by the finger of God that I cast out demons, then certainly the kingdom of God has overtaken you.
verses.textLa: Porro si in digito Dei eiicio dæmonia: profecto pervenit in vos regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: When a strong armed man guards his entrance, the things that he possesses are at peace.
verses.textLa: Cum fortis armatus custodit atrium suum, in pace sunt ea, quæ possidet.

verses.textEn: But if a stronger one, overwhelming him, has defeated him, he will take away all his weapons, in which he trusted, and he will distribute his spoils.
verses.textLa: Si autem fortior eo superveniens vicerit eum, universa arma eius auferet, in quibus confidebat, et spolia eius distribuet.

verses.textEn: Whoever is not with me, is against me. And whoever does not gather with me, scatters.
verses.textLa: Qui non est mecum, contra me est: et qui non colligit mecum, dispergit.

verses.textEn: When an unclean spirit has departed from a man, he walks through waterless places, seeking rest. And not finding any, he says: ‘I will return to my house, from which I departed.’
verses.textLa: Cum immundus spiritus exierit de homine, ambulat per loca inaquosa, quærens requiem: et non inveniens dicit: Revertar in domum meam unde exivi.

verses.textEn: And when he has arrived, he finds it swept clean and decorated.
verses.textLa: Et cum venerit, invenit eam scopis mundatam, et ornatam.

verses.textEn: Then he goes, and he takes in seven other spirits with him, more wicked than himself, and they enter and live there. And so, the end of that man is made worse than the beginning.”
verses.textLa: Tunc vadit, et assumit septem alios spiritus secum, nequiores se, et ingressi habitant ibi. Et fiunt novissima hominis illius peiora prioribus.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when he was saying these things, a certain woman from the crowd, lifting up her voice, said to him, “Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts that nursed you.”
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, cum hæc diceret: extollens vocem quædam mulier de turba dixit illi: Beatus venter, qui te portavit, et ubera, quæ suxisti.

verses.textEn: Then he said, “Yes, but moreover: blessed are those who hear the word of God and keep it.”
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Quinimmo beati, qui audiunt verbum Dei, et custodiunt illud.

verses.textEn: Then, as the crowds were quickly gathering, he began to say: “This generation is a wicked generation: it seeks a sign. But no sign will be given to it, except the sign of the prophet Jonah.
verses.textLa: Turbis autem concurrentibus cœpit dicere: Generatio hæc, generatio nequam est: signum quærit, et signum non dabitur ei, nisi signum Ionæ prophetæ.

verses.textEn: For just as Jonah was a sign to the Ninevites, so also will the Son of man be to this generation.
verses.textLa: Nam sicut fuit Ionas signum Ninivitis: ita erit et Filius hominis generationi isti.

verses.textEn: The queen of the South will rise up, at the judgment, with the men of this generation, and she will condemn them. For she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon. And behold, more than Solomon is here.
verses.textLa: Regina Austri surget in iudicio cum viris generationis huius, et condemnabit illos: quia venit a finibus terræ audire sapientiam Salomonis: et ecce plus quam Salomon hic.

verses.textEn: The men of Nineveh will rise up, at the judgment, with this generation, and they will condemn it. For at the preaching of Jonah, they repented. And behold, more than Jonah is here.
verses.textLa: Viri Ninivitæ surgent in iudicio cum generatione hac, et condemnabunt illam: quia pœnitentiam egerunt ad prædicationem Ionæ, et ecce plus quam Ionas hic.

verses.textEn: No one lights a candle and places it in hiding, nor under a bushel basket, but upon a lampstand, so that those who enter may see the light.
verses.textLa: Nemo lucernam accendit, et in abscondito ponit, neque sub modio: sed supra candelabrum, ut qui ingrediuntur, lumen videant.

verses.textEn: Your eye is the light of your body. If your eye is wholesome, your entire body will be filled with light. But if it is wicked, then even your body will be darkened.
verses.textLa: Lucerna corporis tui, est oculus tuus. Si oculus tuus fuerit simplex, totum corpus tuum lucidum erit: si autem nequam fuerit, etiam corpus tuum tenebrosum erit.

verses.textEn: Therefore, take care, lest the light that is within you become darkness.
verses.textLa: Vide ergo ne lumen, quod in te est, tenebræ sint.

verses.textEn: So then, if your entire body becomes filled with light, not having any part in darkness, then it will be entirely light, and, like a shining lamp, it will illuminate you.”
verses.textLa: Si ergo corpus tuum totum lucidum fuerit, non habens aliquam partem tenebrarum, erit lucidum totum, et sicut lucerna fulgoris illuminabit te.

verses.textEn: And as he was speaking, a certain Pharisee asked him to eat with him. And going inside, he sat down to eat.
verses.textLa: Et cum loqueretur, rogavit illum quidam Pharisæus ut pranderet apud se. Et ingressus recubuit.

verses.textEn: But the Pharisee began to say, thinking within himself: “Why might it be that he has not washed before eating?”
verses.textLa: Pharisæus autem cœpit intra se reputans dicere, quare non baptizatus esset ante prandium.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him: “You Pharisees today clean what is outside the cup and the plate, but what is inside of you is full of plunder and iniquity.
verses.textLa: Et ait Dominus ad illum: Nunc vos Pharisæi quod deforis est calicis, et catini, mundatis: quod autem intus est vestrum, plenum est rapina, et iniquitate.

verses.textEn: Fools! Did not he who made what is outside, indeed also make what is inside?
verses.textLa: Stulti! Nonne qui fecit quod deforis est, etiam id, quod deintus est, fecit?

verses.textEn: Yet truly, give what is above as alms, and behold, all things are clean for you.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen quod superest, date eleemosynam: et ecce omnia munda sunt vobis.
verses.notes: The word ‘superest’ literally means ‘is over’ or ‘is above.’ It is sometimes used to refer to human persons who are still alive, i.e. if you have survived, you are still above ground, not having been buried in a grave. In this context, it refers to the things of this world, to the things of this life, to temporal things.

verses.textEn: But woe to you, Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, but you ignore judgment and the charity of God. But these things you ought to have done, without omitting the others.
verses.textLa: Sed væ vobis Pharisæis, quia decimatis mentham, et rutam, et omne olus, et præteritis iudicium, et charitatem Dei: hæc autem oportuit facere, et illa non omittere.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, Pharisees! For you love the first seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the marketplace.
verses.textLa: Væ vobis Pharisæis, quia diligitis primas cathedras in synagogis, et salutationes in foro.

verses.textEn: Woe to you! For you are like graves that are not noticeable, so that men walk over them without realizing it.”
verses.textLa: Væ vobis, quia estis ut monumenta, quæ non apparent, et homines ambulantes supra, nesciunt.

verses.textEn: Then one of the experts in the law, in response, said to him, “Teacher, in saying these things, you bring an insult against us as well.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem quidam ex legis peritis, ait illi: Magister, hæc dicens etiam contumeliam nobis facis.

verses.textEn: So he said: “And woe to you experts in the law! For you weigh men down with burdens which they are not able to bear, but you yourselves do not touch the weight with even one of your fingers.
verses.textLa: At ille ait: Et vobis legis peritis væ: quia oneratis homines oneribus, quæ portare non possunt, et ipsi uno digito vestro non tangitis sarcinas.
verses.notes: These experts in Jewish law were not so much like the secular lawyers of today (as bad as some from that group can be), but were more like the experts in theology and religion today.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, who build the tombs of the prophets, while it is your fathers who killed them!
verses.textLa: Væ vobis, qui ædificatis monumenta Prophetarum: patres autem vestri occiderunt illos.

verses.textEn: Clearly, you are testifying that you consent to the actions of your fathers, because even though they killed them, you build their sepulchers.
verses.textLa: Profecto testificamini quod consentitis operibus patrum vestrorum: quoniam ipsi quidem eos occiderunt, vos autem ædificatis eorum sepulchra.

verses.textEn: Because of this also, the wisdom of God said: I will send to them Prophets and Apostles, and some of these they will kill or persecute,
verses.textLa: Propterea et sapientia Dei dixit: Mittam ad illos Prophetas, et Apostolos, et ex illis occident, et persequentur:

verses.textEn: so that the blood of all the Prophets, which has been shed since the foundation of the world, may be charged against this generation:
verses.textLa: ut inquiratur sanguis omnium Prophetarum, qui effusus est a constitutione mundi a generatione ista,

verses.textEn: from the blood of Abel, even to the blood of Zachariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary. So I say to you: it will be required of this generation!
verses.textLa: a sanguine Abel, usque ad sanguinem Zachariæ, qui periit inter altare, et ædem. Ita dico vobis, requiretur ab hac generatione.
verses.notes: The word ‘aedem’ is used more to refer to smaller shrines or temples, and so it evidently does not refer to the Temple of Jerusalem.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, experts in the law! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You yourselves do not enter, and those who were entering, you would have prohibited.”
verses.textLa: Væ vobis legis peritis, quia tulistis clavem scientiæ, ipsi non introistis, et eos, qui introibant, prohibuistis.

verses.textEn: Then, while he was saying these things to them, the Pharisees and the experts in the law began to insist strongly that he restrain his mouth about many things.
verses.textLa: Cum autem hæc ad illos diceret, cœperunt Pharisæi, et Legisperiti graviter insistere, et os eius opprimere de multis,

verses.textEn: And waiting to ambush him, they sought something from his mouth that they might seize upon, in order to accuse him.
verses.textLa: insidiantes ei, et quærentes aliquid capere de ore eius, ut accusarent eum.

verses.textEn: Then, as great crowds were standing so close that they were stepping on one another, he began to say to his disciples: “Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.
verses.textLa: Multis autem turbis circumstantibus, ita ut se invicem conculcarent, cœpit dicere ad discipulos suos: Attendite a fermento Pharisæorum, quod est hypocrisis.

verses.textEn: For there is nothing covered, which will not be revealed, nor anything hidden, which will not be known.
verses.textLa: Nihil autem opertum est, quod non reveletur: neque absconditum, quod non sciatur.

verses.textEn: For the things that you have spoken in darkness will be declared in the light. And what you have said in the ear in bedrooms will be proclaimed from the housetops.
verses.textLa: Quoniam quæ in tenebris dixistis, in lumine dicentur: et quod in aurem locuti estis in cubiculis, prædicabitur in tectis.

verses.textEn: So I say to you, my friends: Do not be fearful of those who kill the body, and afterwards have no more that they can do.
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis amicis meis: Ne terreamini ab his, qui occidunt corpus, et post hæc non habent amplius quid faciant.

verses.textEn: But I will reveal to you whom you should fear. Fear him who, after he will have killed, has the power to cast into Hell. So I say to you: Fear him.
verses.textLa: Ostendam autem vobis quem timeatis: timete eum, qui, postquam occiderit, habet potestatem mittere in gehennam. Ita dico vobis, hunc timete.

verses.textEn: Are not five sparrows sold for two small coins? And yet not one of these is forgotten in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Nonne quinque passeres væneunt dipondio, et unus ex illis non est in oblivione coram Deo?

verses.textEn: But even the very hairs of your head have all been numbered. Therefore, do not be afraid. You are worth more than many sparrows.
verses.textLa: Sed et capilli capitis vestri omnes numerati sunt. Nolite ergo timere: multis passeribus pluris estis vos:

verses.textEn: But I say to you: Everyone who will have confessed me before men, the Son of man will also confess him before the Angels of God.
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis: Omnis, quicumque confessus fuerit me coram hominibus, et Filius hominis confitebitur illum coram Angelis Dei:

verses.textEn: But everyone who will have denied me before men, he will be denied before the Angels of God.
verses.textLa: qui autem negaverit me coram hominibus, negabitur coram Angelis Dei.

verses.textEn: And everyone who speaks a word against the Son of man, it will be forgiven of him. But of him who will have blasphemed against the Holy Spirit, it will not be forgiven.
verses.textLa: Et omnis qui dicit verbum in Filium hominis, remittetur illi: ei autem, qui in Spiritum Sanctum blasphemaverit, non remittetur.

verses.textEn: And when they will lead you to the synagogues, and to magistrates and authorities, do not choose to be worried about how or what you will answer, or about what you might say.
verses.textLa: Cum autem inducent vos in synagogas, et ad magistratus, et potestates, nolite soliciti esse qualiter, aut quid respondeatis, aut quid dicatis.

verses.textEn: For the Holy Spirit will teach you, in the same hour, what you must say.”
verses.textLa: Spiritus enim Sanctus docebit vos in ipsa hora quid oporteat vos dicere.

verses.textEn: And someone from the crowd said to him, “Teacher, tell my brother to share the inheritance with me.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem ei quidam de turba: Magister, dic fratri meo ut dividat mecum hereditatem.

verses.textEn: But he said to him, “Man, who has appointed me as judge or arbitrator over you?”
verses.textLa: At ille dixit illi: Homo, quis me constituit iudicem, aut divisorem super vos?

verses.textEn: So he said to them: “Be cautious and wary of all avarice. For a person’s life is not found in the abundance of the things that he possesses.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad illos: Videte, et cavete ab omni avaritia: quia non in abundantia cuiusquam vita eius est ex his quæ possidet.

verses.textEn: Then he spoke to them using a comparison, saying: “The fertile land of a certain wealthy man produced crops.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem similitudinem ad illos, dicens: Hominis cuiusdam divitis uberes fructus ager attulit:

verses.textEn: And he thought within himself, saying: ‘What should I do? For I have nowhere to gather together my crops.’
verses.textLa: et cogitabat intra se dicens: Quid faciam, quia non habeo quo congregam fructus meos?

verses.textEn: And he said: ‘This is what I will do. I will tear down my barns and build larger ones. And into these, I will gather all the things that have been grown for me, as well as my goods.
verses.textLa: Et dixit: Hoc faciam: Destruam horrea mea, et maiora faciam: et illuc congregabo omnia, quæ nata sunt mihi, et bona mea,

verses.textEn: And I will say to my soul: Soul, you have many goods, stored up for many years. Relax, eat, drink, and be cheerful.’
verses.textLa: et dicam animæ meæ: Anima, habes multa bona posita in annos plurimos: requiesce, comede, bibe, epulare.

verses.textEn: But God said to him: ‘Foolish one, this very night they require your soul of you. To whom, then, will those things belong, which you have prepared?’
verses.textLa: Dixit autem illi Deus: Stulte, hac nocte animam tuam repetunt a te: quæ autem parasti, cuius erunt?

verses.textEn: So it is with him who stores up for himself, and is not wealthy with God.”
verses.textLa: Sic est qui sibi thesaurizat, et non est in Deum dives.

verses.textEn: And he said to his disciples: “And so I say to you: Do not choose to be anxious about your life, as to what you may eat, nor about your body, as to what you will wear.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad discipulos suos: Ideo dico vobis: Nolite soliciti esse animæ vestræ quid manducetis: neque corpori quid induamini.

verses.textEn: Life is more than food, and the body is more than clothing.
verses.textLa: Anima plus est quam esca, et corpus plus quam vestimentum.

verses.textEn: Consider the ravens. For they neither sow nor reap; there is no storehouse or barn for them. And yet God pastures them. How much more are you, compared to them?
verses.textLa: Considerate corvos quia non seminant, neque metunt, quibus non est cellarium, neque horreum, et Deus pascit illos. Quanto magis vos pluris estis illis?

verses.textEn: But which of you, by thinking, is able to add one cubit to his stature?
verses.textLa: Quis autem vestrum cogitando potest adiicere ad staturam suam cubitum unum?

verses.textEn: Therefore, if you are not capable, in what is so little, why be anxious about the rest?
verses.textLa: Si ergo neque quod minimum est potestis, quid de ceteris soliciti estis?

verses.textEn: Consider the lilies, how they grow. They neither work nor weave. But I say to you, not even Solomon, in all his glory, was clothed like one of these.
verses.textLa: Considerate lilia quomodo crescunt: non laborant, neque nent: dico autem vobis, nec Salomon in omni gloria sua vestiebatur sicut unum ex istis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if God so clothes the grass, which is in the field today and thrown into the furnace tomorrow, how much more you, O little in faith?
verses.textLa: Si autem fœnum, quod hodie est in agro, et cras in clibanum mittitur, Deus sic vestit: quanto magis vos pusillæ fidei?

verses.textEn: And so, do not choose to inquire as to what you will eat, or what you will drink. And do not choose to be lifted up on high.
