verses.textLa: Et vos nolite quærere quid manducetis, aut quid bibatis: et nolite in sublime tolli:

verses.textEn: For all these things are sought by the Gentiles of the world. And your Father knows that you have need of these things.
verses.textLa: hæc enim omnia gentes mundi quærunt. Pater autem vester scit quoniam his indigetis.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, seek first the kingdom of God, and his justice, and all these things shall be added to you.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen quærite primum regnum Dei, et iustitiam eius: et hæc omnia adiicientur vobis.

verses.textEn: Do not be afraid, little flock; for it has pleased your Father to give you the kingdom.
verses.textLa: Nolite timere pusillus grex, quia complacuit Patri vestro dare vobis regnum.

verses.textEn: Sell what you possess, and give alms. Make for yourselves purses that will not wear out, a treasure that will not fall short, in heaven, where no thief approaches, and no moth corrupts.
verses.textLa: Vendite quæ possidetis, et date eleemosynam. Facite vobis sacculos, qui non veterascunt, thesaurum non deficientem in cælis: quo fur non appropriat, neque tinea corrumpit.

verses.textEn: For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.
verses.textLa: Ubi enim thesaurus vester est, ibi et cor vestrum erit.

verses.textEn: Let your waists be girded, and let lamps be burning in your hands.
verses.textLa: Sint lumbi vestri præcincti, et lucernæ ardentes in manibus vestris,
verses.notes: The word ‘lumbi’ (loins) actually refers to the lower back, or to the waistline, which in ancient times was considered to be at the level of the kidneys and lower back, not at the hips.

verses.textEn: And let you yourselves be like men awaiting their lord, when he will return from the wedding; so that, when he arrives and knocks, they may open to him promptly.
verses.textLa: et vos similes hominibus expectantibus dominum suum, quando revertatur a nuptiis: ut, cum venerit, et pulsaverit, confestim aperiant ei.

verses.textEn: Blessed are those servants whom the Lord, when he returns, will find being vigilant. Amen I say to you, that he will gird himself and have them sit down to eat, while he, continuing on, will minister to them.
verses.textLa: Beati servi illi, quos cum venerit Dominus, invenerit vigilantes: amen dico vobis, quod præcinget se, et faciet illos discumbere, et transiens ministrabit illis.

verses.textEn: And if he will return in the second watch, or if in the third watch, and if he will find them to be so: then blessed are those servants.
verses.textLa: Et si venerit in secunda vigilia, et si in tertia vigilia venerit, et ita invenerit, beati sunt servi illi.

verses.textEn: But know this: that if the father of the family knew at what hour the thief would arrive, he would certainly stand watch, and he would not permit his house to be broken into.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem scitote, quoniam si sciret paterfamilias, qua hora fur veniret, vigilaret utique, et non sineret perfodi domum suam.

verses.textEn: You also must be prepared. For the Son of man will return at an hour that you will not realize.”
verses.textLa: Et vos estote parati: quia qua hora non putatis, Filius hominis veniet.

verses.textEn: Then Peter said to him, “Lord, are you telling this parable to us, or also to everyone?”
verses.textLa: Ait autem et Petrus: Domine, ad nos dicis hanc parabolam: an et ad omnes?

verses.textEn: So the Lord said: “Who do you think is the faithful and prudent steward, whom his Lord has appointed over his family, in order to give them their measure of wheat in due time?
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus: Quis, putas, est fidelis dispensator, et prudens, quem constituit Dominus supra familiam suam, ut det illis in tempore tritici mensuram?

verses.textEn: Blessed is that servant if, when his Lord will return, he will find him acting in this manner.
verses.textLa: Beatus ille servus, quem cum venerit Dominus, invenerit ita facientem.

verses.textEn: Truly I say to you, that he will appoint him over all that he possesses.
verses.textLa: Vere dico vobis, quoniam supra omnia, quæ possidet, constituet illum.

verses.textEn: But if that servant will have said in his heart, ‘My Lord has made a delay in his return,’ and if he has begun to strike the men and women servants, and to eat and drink, and to be inebriated,
verses.textLa: Quod si dixerit servus ille in corde suo: Moram facit Dominus meus venire: et cœperit percutere servos, et ancillas, et edere, et bibere, et inebriari:

verses.textEn: then the Lord of that servant will return on a day which he hoped not, and at an hour which he knew not. And he will separate him, and he will place his portion with that of the unfaithful.
verses.textLa: veniet Dominus servi illius in die, qua non sperat, et hora, qua nescit, et dividet eum, partemque eius cum infidelibus ponet.

verses.textEn: And that servant, who knew the will of his Lord, and who did not prepare and did not act according to his will, will be beaten many times over.
verses.textLa: Ille autem servus, qui cognovit voluntatem Domini sui, et non præparavit, et non facit secundum voluntatem eius, vapulabit multis:

verses.textEn: Yet he who did not know, and who acted in a way that deserves a beating, will be beaten fewer times. So then, of all to whom much has been given, much will be required. And of those to whom much has been entrusted, even more will be asked.
verses.textLa: qui autem non cognovit, et fecit digna plagis, vapulabit paucis. Omni autem, cui multum datum est, multum quæretur ab eo: et cui commendaverunt multum, plus petent ab eo.

verses.textEn: I have come to cast a fire upon the earth. And what should I desire, except that it may be kindled?
verses.textLa: Ignem veni mittere in terram, et quid volo nisi ut accendatur?

verses.textEn: And I have a baptism, with which I am to be baptized. And how I am constrained, even until it may be accomplished!
verses.textLa: Baptismo autem habeo baptizari: et quomodo coarctor usque dum perficiatur!

verses.textEn: Do you think that I have come to give peace to the earth? No, I tell you, but division.
verses.textLa: Putatis quia pacem veni dare in terram? Non, dico vobis, sed separationem:

verses.textEn: For from this time on, there will be five in one house: divided as three against two, and as two against three.
verses.textLa: erunt enim ex hoc quinque in domo una divisi, tres in duos, et duo in tres

verses.textEn: A father will be divided against a son, and a son against his father; a mother against a daughter and a daughter against a mother; a mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law, and a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.”
verses.textLa: dividentur: pater in filium, et filius in patrem suum, mater in filiam, et filia in matrem, socrus in nurum suam, et nurus in socrum suam.

verses.textEn: And he also said to the crowds: “When you see a cloud rising from the setting of the sun, immediately you say, ‘A rain cloud is coming.’ And so it does.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et ad turbas: Cum videritis nubem orientem ab occasu, statim dicitis: Nimbus venit: et ita fit.

verses.textEn: And when a south wind is blowing, you say, ‘It will be hot.’ And so it is.
verses.textLa: Et cum austrum flantem, dicitis: Quia æstus erit: et fit.

verses.textEn: You hypocrites! You discern the face of the heavens, and of the earth, yet how is it that you do not discern this time?
verses.textLa: Hypocritæ faciem cæli, et terræ nostis probare: hoc autem tempus quomodo non probatis?

verses.textEn: And why do you not, even among yourselves, judge what is just?
verses.textLa: Quid autem et a vobis ipsis non iudicatis quod iustum est?

verses.textEn: So, when you are going with your adversary to the ruler, while you are on the way, make an effort to be freed from him, lest perhaps he may lead you to the judge, and the judge may deliver you to the officer, and the officer may cast you into prison.
verses.textLa: Cum autem vadis cum adversario tuo ad principem, in via da operam liberari ab illo, ne forte trahat te ad iudicem, et iudex tradat te exactori, et exactor mittat te in carcerem.

verses.textEn: I tell you, you will not depart from there, until you have paid the very last coin.”
verses.textLa: Dico tibi, non exies inde, donec etiam novissimum minutum reddas.

verses.textEn: And there were present, at that very time, some who were reporting about the Galileans, whose blood Pilate mixed with their sacrifices.
verses.textLa: Aderant autem quidam ipso in tempore, nunciantes illi de Galilæis, quorum sanguinem Pilatus miscuit cum sacrificiis eorum.
verses.notes: The wording of this verse in Latin gives the impression that this was a current event.

verses.textEn: And responding, he said to them: “Do you think that these Galileans must have sinned more than all other Galileans, because they suffered so much?
verses.textLa: Et respondens dixit illis: Putatis quod hi Galilæi præ omnibus Galilæis peccatores fuerint, quia talia passi sunt?

verses.textEn: No, I tell you. But unless you repent, you will all perish similarly.
verses.textLa: Non, dico vobis: sed nisi pœnitentiam habueritis, omnes similiter peribitis.

verses.textEn: And those eighteen upon whom the tower of Siloam fell and killed them, do you think that they also were greater transgressors than all the men living in Jerusalem?
verses.textLa: Sicut illi decem et octo, supra quos cecidit turris in Siloe, et occidit eos: putatis quia et ipsi debitores fuerint præter omnes homines habitantes in Ierusalem?

verses.textEn: No, I tell you. But if you do not repent, you will all perish similarly.”
verses.textLa: Non, dico vobis: sed si pœnitentiam non egeritis, omnes similiter peribitis.

verses.textEn: And he also told this parable: “A certain man had a fig tree, which was planted in his vineyard. And he came seeking fruit on it, but found none.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et hanc similitudinem: Arborem fici habebat quidam plantatam in vinea sua, et venit quærens fructum in illa, et non invenit.

verses.textEn: Then he said to the cultivator of the vineyard: ‘Behold, for these three years I came seeking fruit on this fig tree, and I have found none. Therefore, cut it down. For why should it even occupy the land?’
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ad cultorem vineæ: Ecce anni tres sunt ex quo venio quærens fructum in ficulnea hac, et non invenio: succide ergo illam: ut quid etiam terram occupat?

verses.textEn: But in response, he said to him: ‘Lord, let it be for this year also, during which time I will dig around it and add fertilizer.
verses.textLa: At ille respondens, dicit illi: Domine dimitte illam et hoc anno, usque dum fodiam circa illam, et mittam stercora:

verses.textEn: And, indeed, it should bear fruit. But if not, in the future, you shall cut it down.’ ”
verses.textLa: et siquidem fecerit fructum: sin autem, in futurum succides eam.

verses.textEn: Now he was teaching in their synagogue on the Sabbaths.
verses.textLa: Erat autem docens in synagoga eorum Sabbatis.

verses.textEn: And behold, there was a woman who had a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years. And she was bent over; and she was unable to look upwards at all.
verses.textLa: Et ecce mulier, quæ habebat spiritum infirmitatis annis decem et octo: et erat inclinata, nec omnino poterat sursum respicere.

verses.textEn: And when Jesus saw her, he called her to himself, and he said to her, “Woman, you are released from your infirmity.”
verses.textLa: Quam cum videret Iesus, vocavit eam ad se, et ait illi: Mulier, dimissa es ab infirmitate tua.

verses.textEn: And he laid his hands upon her, and immediately she was straightened, and she glorified God.
verses.textLa: Et imposuit illi manus, et confestim erecta est, et glorificabat Deum.

verses.textEn: Then, as a result, the ruler of the synagogue became angry that Jesus had cured on the Sabbath, and he said to the crowd: “There are six days on which you ought to work. Therefore, come and be cured on those, and not on the day of the Sabbath.”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem archisynagogus, indignans quia Sabbato curasset Iesus: dicebat turbæ: Sex dies sunt, in quibus oportet operari: in his ergo venite, et curamini, et non in die Sabbati.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to him in response: “You hypocrites! Does not each one of you, on the Sabbath, release his ox or donkey from the stall, and lead it to water?
verses.textLa: Respondens autem ad illum Dominus dixit: Hypocritæ, unusquisque vestrum Sabbato non solvit bovem suum, aut asinum a præsepio, et ducit adaquare?

verses.textEn: So then, should not this daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has bound for lo these eighteen years, be released from this restraint on the day of the Sabbath?”
verses.textLa: Hanc autem filiam Abrahæ, quam alligavit Satanas, ecce decem et octo annis non oportuit solvi a vinculo isto die Sabbati?

verses.textEn: And as he was saying these things, all his adversaries were ashamed. And all the people rejoiced in everything that was being done gloriously by him.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc diceret, erubescebant omnes adversarii eius: et omnis populus gaudebat in universis, quæ gloriose fiebant ab eo.

verses.textEn: And so he said: “To what is the kingdom of God similar, and to what figure shall I compare it?
verses.textLa: Dicebat ergo: Cui simile est regnum Dei, et cui simile æstimabo illud?

verses.textEn: It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and cast into his garden. And it grew, and it became a great tree, and the birds of the air rested in its branches.”
verses.textLa: Simile est grano sinapis, quod acceptum homo misit in hortum suum, et crevit, et factum est in arborem magnam: et volucres cæli requieverunt in ramis eius.

verses.textEn: And again, he said: “To what figure shall I compare the kingdom of God?
verses.textLa: Et iterum dixit: Cui simile æstimabo regnum Dei?

verses.textEn: It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of fine wheat flour, until it was entirely leavened.”
verses.textLa: Simile est fermento, quod acceptum mulier abscondit in farinæ sata tria, donec fermentaretur totum.

verses.textEn: And he was traveling through the cities and towns, teaching and making his way to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et ibat per civitates, et castella docens, et iter faciens in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And someone said to him, “Lord, are they few who are saved?” But he said to them:
verses.textLa: Ait autem illi quidam: Domine, si pauci sunt, qui salvantur? Ipse autem dixit ad illos:

verses.textEn: “Strive to enter through the narrow gate. For many, I tell you, will seek to enter and not be able.
verses.textLa: Contendite intrare per angustam portam: quia multi, dico vobis, quærent intrare, et non poterunt.

verses.textEn: Then, when the father of the family will have entered and shut the door, you will begin to stand outside and to knock at the door, saying, ‘Lord, open to us.’ And in response, he will say to you, ‘I do not know where you are from.’
verses.textLa: Cum autem intraverit paterfamilias, et clauserit ostium, incipietis foris stare, et pulsare ostium, dicentes: Domine, aperi nobis: et respondens dicet vobis: Nescio vos unde sitis:

verses.textEn: Then you will begin to say, ‘We ate and drank in your presence, and you taught in our streets.’
verses.textLa: tunc incipietis dicere: Manducavimus coram te, et bibimus, et in plateis nostris docuisti.

verses.textEn: And he will say to you: ‘I do not know where you are from. Depart from me, all you workers of iniquity!’
verses.textLa: Et dicet vobis: Nescio vos unde sitis: discedite a me omnes operarii iniquitatis.

verses.textEn: In that place, there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets, in the kingdom of God, yet you yourselves are expelled outside.
verses.textLa: Ibi erit fletus, et stridor dentium: cum videritis Abraham, et Isaac, et Iacob, et omnes Prophetas in regno Dei, vos autem expelli foras.

verses.textEn: And they will arrive from the East, and the West, and the North, and the South; and they will recline at table in the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Et venient ab Oriente, et Occidente, et Aquilone, et Austro, et accumbent in regno Dei.

verses.textEn: And behold, those who are last will be first, and those who are first will be last.”
verses.textLa: Et ecce sunt novissimi qui erunt primi, et sunt primi qui erunt novissimi.

verses.textEn: On the same day, some of the Pharisees approached, saying to him: “Depart, and go away from here. For Herod wishes to kill you.”
verses.textLa: In ipsa die accesserunt quidam Pharisæorum, dicentes illi: Exi, et vade hinc: quia Herodes vult te occidere.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Go and tell that fox: ‘Behold, I cast out demons and accomplish healings, today and tomorrow. And on the third day I reach the end.’
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Ite, et dicite vulpi illi: Ecce eiicio dæmonia, et sanitates perficio hodie, et cras, et tertia die consummor.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, it is necessary for me to walk today and tomorrow and the following day. For it does not fall to a prophet to perish beyond Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen oportet me hodie et cras et sequenti die ambulare: quia non capit prophetam perire extra Ierusalem.
verses.notes: Literally, ‘it does not seize upon a prophet to perish’. The word ‘capit’ is used somewhat idiomatically here.

verses.textEn: Jerusalem, Jerusalem! You kill the prophets, and you stone those who are sent to you. Daily, I wanted to gather together your children, in the manner of a bird with her nest under her wings, but you were not willing!
verses.textLa: Ierusalem, Ierusalem, quæ occidis Prophetas, et lapidas eos, qui mittuntur ad te, quoties volui congregare filios tuos quemadmodum avis nidum suum sub pennis, et noluisti?
verses.notes: The word ‘nidum’ means ‘nest’ not ‘brood.’ Jerusalem is compared to a nest, and Jesus is compared to the mother-hen of that nest, protecting her young and the place of rest and safety for her young. But the nest was unwilling to accept it owner.

verses.textEn: Behold, your house will be left desolate for you. But I say to you, that you shall not see me, until it happens that you say: ‘Blessed is he who has arrived in the name of the Lord.’ ”
verses.textLa: Ecce relinquetur vobis domus vestra deserta. Dico autem vobis, quia non videbitis me donec veniat cum dicetis: Benedictus, qui venit in nomine Domini.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when Jesus entered the house of a certain leader of the Pharisees on the Sabbath to eat bread, they were observing him.
verses.textLa: Et factum est cum intraret Iesus in domum cuiusdam principis Pharisæorum Sabbato manducare panem, et ipsi observabant eum.

verses.textEn: And behold, a certain man before him was afflicted with edema.
verses.textLa: Et ecce homo quidam hydropicus erat ante illum.

verses.textEn: And responding, Jesus spoke to the experts in the law and to the Pharisees, saying, “Is it lawful to cure on the Sabbath?”
verses.textLa: Et respondens Iesus dixit ad legis peritos, et Pharisæos, dicens: Si licet Sabbato curare?

verses.textEn: But they kept silent. Yet truly, taking hold of him, he healed him and sent him away.
verses.textLa: At illi tacuerunt. Ipse vero apprehensum sanavit eum, ac dimisit.

verses.textEn: And responding to them, he said, “Which of you will have a donkey or an ox fall into a pit, and will not promptly pull him out, on the day of the Sabbath?”
verses.textLa: Et respondens ad illos dixit: Cuius vestrum asinus, aut bos in puteum cadet, et non continuo extrahet illum die Sabbati?

verses.textEn: And they were unable to respond to him about these things.
verses.textLa: Et non poterant ad hæc respondere illi.

verses.textEn: Then he also told a parable, to those who were invited, noticing how they chose the first seats at the table, saying to them:
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et ad invitatos parabolam, intendens quomodo primos accubitus eligerent, dicens ad illos:

verses.textEn: “When you are invited to a wedding, do not sit down in the first place, lest perhaps someone more honored than yourself may have been invited by him.
verses.textLa: Cum invitatus fueris ad nuptias, non discumbas in primo loco, ne forte honoratior te sit invitatus ab illo,

verses.textEn: And then he who called both you and him, approaching, may say to you, ‘Give this place to him.’ And then you would begin, with shame, to take the last place.
verses.textLa: et veniens is, qui te et illum vocavit, dicat tibi: Da huic locum: et tunc incipias cum rubore novissimum locum tenere.

verses.textEn: But when you are invited, go, sit down in the lowest place, so that, when he who invited you arrives, he may say to you, ‘Friend, go up higher.’ Then you will have glory in the sight of those who sit at table together with you.
verses.textLa: Sed cum vocatus fueris, vade, recumbe in novissimo loco: ut, cum venerit qui te invitavit, dicat tibi: Amice, ascende superius. Tunc erit tibi gloria coram simul discumbentibus:

verses.textEn: For everyone who exalts himself shall be humbled, and whoever humbles himself shall be exalted.”
verses.textLa: quia omnis, qui se exaltat, humiliabitur: et qui se humiliat, exaltabitur.

verses.textEn: Then he also said to the one who had invited him: “When you prepare a lunch or dinner, do not choose to call your friends, or your brothers, or your relatives, or your wealthy neighbors, lest perhaps they might then invite you in return and repayment would made to you.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et ei, qui invitaverat: Cum facis prandium, aut cœnam, noli vocare amicos tuos, neque fratres tuos, neque cognatos, neque vicinos divites: ne forte te et ipsi reinvitent, et fiat tibi retributio.

verses.textEn: But when you prepare a feast, call the poor, the disabled, the lame, and the blind.
verses.textLa: Sed cum facis convivium, voca pauperes, debiles, claudos, et cæcos:

verses.textEn: And you will be blessed because they do not have a way to repay you. So then, your recompense will be in the resurrection of the just.”
verses.textLa: et beatus eris, quia non habent retribuere tibi: retribuetur enim tibi in resurrectione iustorum.

verses.textEn: When someone sitting at table with him had heard these things, he said to him, “Blessed is he who will eat bread in the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Hæc cum audisset quidam de simul discumbentibus, dixit illi: Beatus, qui manducabit panem in regno Dei.

verses.textEn: So he said to him: “A certain man prepared a great feast, and he invited many.
verses.textLa: At ipse dixit ei: Homo quidam fecit cœnam magnam, et vocavit multos.

verses.textEn: And he sent his servant, at the hour of the feast, to tell the invited to come; for now everything was ready.
verses.textLa: Et misit servum suum hora cœnæ dicere invitatis ut venirent, quia iam parata sunt omnia.

verses.textEn: And at once they all began to make excuses. The first said to him: ‘I bought a farm, and I need to go out and see it. I ask you to excuse me.’
verses.textLa: Et cœperunt simul omnes excusare. Primus dixit ei: Villam emi, et necesse habeo exire, et videre illam: rogo te habe me excusatum.

verses.textEn: And another said: ‘I bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to examine them. I ask you to excuse me.’
verses.textLa: Et alter dixit: Iuga boum emi quinque, et eo probare illa: rogo te habe me excusatum.
verses.notes: How many oxen did he buy? Ten, i.e. five pairs, each pair being yoked together when working.

verses.textEn: And another said, ‘I have taken a wife, and therefore I am not able to go.’
verses.textLa: Et alius dixit: Uxorem duxi, et ideo non possum venire.

verses.textEn: And returning, the servant reported these things to his lord. Then the father of the family, becoming angry, said to his servant: ‘Go out quickly into the streets and neighborhoods of the city. And lead here the poor, and the disabled, and the blind, and the lame.’
verses.textLa: Et reversus servus nunciavit hæc domino suo. Tunc iratus paterfamilias, dixit servo suo: Exi cito in plateas, et vicos civitatis: et pauperes, ac debiles, et cæcos, et claudos introduc huc.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘plateas et vicos’ refers to the broader main streets and to the narrower side streets of the city. The word vicos can also refer to the neighborhoods within the larger city, which are traveled by those side streets.

verses.textEn: And the servant said: ‘It has been done, just as you ordered, lord, and there is still room.’
verses.textLa: Et ait servus: domine, factum est ut imperasti, et adhuc locus est.

verses.textEn: And the lord said to the servant: ‘Go out to the highways and hedges, and compel them to enter, so that my house may be filled.
verses.textLa: Et ait dominus servo: Exi in vias, et sepes: et compelle intrare, ut impleatur domus mea.
verses.notes: The phrase ‘vias, et sepes’ refers to main highways traveled between cities and to the less traveled paths, which might be lined with hedges or bushes, or overgrown with weeds.

verses.textEn: For I tell you, that none of those men who were invited will taste of my feast.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis quod nemo virorum illorum, qui vocati sunt, gustabit cœnam meam.

verses.textEn: Now great crowds traveled with him. And turning around, he said to them:
verses.textLa: Ibant autem turbæ multæ cum eo: et conversus dixit ad illos:

verses.textEn: “If anyone comes to me, and does not hate his father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brothers, and sisters, and yes, even his own life, he is not able to be my disciple.
verses.textLa: Si quis venit ad me, et non odit patrem suum, et matrem, et uxorem, et filios, et fratres, et sorores, adhuc autem et animam suam, non potest meus esse discipulus.

verses.textEn: And whoever does not bear his cross and come after me, is not able to be my disciple.
verses.textLa: Et qui non baiulat crucem suam, et venit post me, non potest meus esse discipulus.

verses.textEn: For who among you, wanting to build a tower, would not first sit down and determine the costs that are required, to see if he has the means to complete it?
verses.textLa: Quis enim ex vobis volens turrim ædificare, non prius sedens computat sumptus, qui necessarii sunt, si habeat ad perficiendum,

verses.textEn: Otherwise, after he will have laid the foundation and not been able to finish it, everyone who sees it may begin to mock him,
verses.textLa: ne, posteaquam posuerit fundamentum, et non potuerit perficere, omnes, qui vident, incipiant illudere ei,

verses.textEn: saying: ‘This man began to build what he was not able to finish.’
verses.textLa: dicentes: Quia hic homo cœpit ædificare, et non potuit consummare?

verses.textEn: Or, what king, advancing to engage in war against another king, would not first sit down and consider whether he may be able, with ten thousand, to meet one who comes against him with twenty thousand?
verses.textLa: Aut quis rex iturus committere bellum adversus alium regem, non sedens prius cogitat, si possit cum decem millibus occurrere ei, qui cum viginti millibus venit ad se?

verses.textEn: If not, then while the other is still far away, sending a delegation, he would ask him for terms of peace.
verses.textLa: Alioquin adhuc illo longe agente, legationem mittens rogat ea, quæ pacis sunt.

verses.textEn: Therefore, every one of you who does not renounce all that he possesses is not able to be my disciple.
verses.textLa: Sic ergo omnis ex vobis, qui non renunciat omnibus, quæ possidet, non potest meus esse discipulus.

verses.textEn: Salt is good. But if the salt has lost its flavor, with what will it be seasoned?
verses.textLa: Bonum est sal. Si autem sal evanuerit, in quo condietur?

verses.textEn: It is useful neither in soil, nor in manure, so instead, it shall be thrown away. Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”
verses.textLa: Neque in terram, neque in sterquilinium utile est, sed foras mittetur. Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.

verses.textEn: Now tax collectors and sinners were drawing near to him, so that they might listen to him.
verses.textLa: Erant autem appropinquantes ei publicani, et peccatores ut audirent illum.

verses.textEn: And the Pharisees and the scribes murmured, saying, “This one accepts sinners and eats with them.”
verses.textLa: Et murmurabant Pharisæi, et scribæ, dicentes: Quia hic peccatores recipit, et manducat cum illis.

verses.textEn: And he told this parable to them, saying:
verses.textLa: Et ait ad illos parabolam istam, dicens:

verses.textEn: “What man among you, who has one hundred sheep, and if he will have lost one of them, would not leave the ninety-nine in the desert and go after the one whom he had lost, until he finds it?
verses.textLa: Quis ex vobis homo, qui habet centum oves: et si perdiderit unam ex illis, nonne dimittit nonaginta novem in deserto, et vadit ad illam, quæ perierat, donec inveniat eam?

verses.textEn: And when he has found it, he places it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
verses.textLa: Et cum invenerit eam, imponit in humeros suos gaudens:

verses.textEn: And returning home, he calls together his friends and neighbors, saying to them: ‘Congratulate me! For I have found my sheep, which had been lost.’
verses.textLa: et veniens domum convocat amicos, et vicinos, dicens illis: Congratulamini mihi quia inveni ovem meam, quæ perierat.

verses.textEn: I say to you, that there will be so much more joy in heaven over one sinner repenting, than over the ninety-nine just, who do not need to repent.
verses.textLa: Dico vobis quod ita gaudium erit in cælo super uno peccatore pœnitentiam agente, quam super nonaginta novem iustis, qui non indigent pœnitentia.

verses.textEn: Or what woman, having ten drachmas, if she will have lost one drachma, would not light a candle, and sweep the house, and diligently search until she finds it?
verses.textLa: Aut quæ mulier habens drachmas decem, si perdiderit drachmam unam, nonne accendit lucernam, et everrit domum, et quærit diligenter, donec inveniat?

verses.textEn: And when she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying: ‘Rejoice with me! For I have found the drachma, which I had lost.’
verses.textLa: Et cum invenerit, convocat amicas, et vicinas, dicens: Congratulamini mihi, quia inveni drachmam, quam perdideram?

verses.textEn: So I say to you, there will be joy before the Angels of God over even one sinner who is repentant.”
verses.textLa: Ita dico vobis, gaudium erit coram Angelis Dei super uno peccatore pœnitentiam agente.

verses.textEn: And he said: “A certain man had two sons.
verses.textLa: Ait autem: Homo quidam habuit duos filios:

verses.textEn: And the younger of them said to the father, ‘Father, give me the portion of your estate which would go to me.’ And he divided the estate between them.
verses.textLa: et dixit adolescentior ex illis patri: Pater, da mihi portionem substantiæ, quæ me contingit. Et divisit illis substantiam.

verses.textEn: And after not many days, the younger son, gathering it all together, set out on a long journey to a distant region. And there, he dissipated his substance, living in luxury.
verses.textLa: Et non post multos dies, congregatis omnibus, adolescentior filius peregre profectus est in regionem longinquam, et ibi dissipavit substantiam suam vivendo luxuriose.

verses.textEn: And after he had consumed it all, a great famine occurred in that region, and he began to be in need.
verses.textLa: Et postquam omnia consummasset, facta est fames valida in regione illa, et ipse cœpit egere.

verses.textEn: And he went and attached himself to one of the citizens of that region. And he sent him to his farm, in order to feed the swine.
verses.textLa: Et abiit, et adhæsit uni civium regionis illius. Et misit illum in villam suam ut pasceret porcos.

verses.textEn: And he wanted to fill his belly with the scraps that the swine ate. But no one would give it to him.
verses.textLa: Et cupiebat implere ventrem suum de siliquis, quas porci manducabant: et nemo illi dabat.

verses.textEn: And returning to his senses, he said: ‘How many hired hands in my father’s house have abundant bread, while I perish here in famine!
verses.textLa: In se autem reversus, dixit: Quanti mercenarii in domo patris mei abundant panibus, ego autem hic fame pereo!

verses.textEn: I shall rise up and go to my father, and I will say to him: Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you.
verses.textLa: Surgam, et ibo ad patrem meum, et dicam ei: Pater, peccavi in cælum, et coram te:

verses.textEn: I am not worthy to be called your son. Make me one of your hired hands.’
verses.textLa: iam non sum dignus vocari filius tuus: fac me sicut unum de mercenariis tuis.

verses.textEn: And rising up, he went to his father. But while he was still at a distance, his father saw him, and he was moved with compassion, and running to him, he fell upon his neck and kissed him.
verses.textLa: Et surgens venit ad patrem suum. Cum autem adhuc longe esset, vidit illum pater ipsius, et misericordia motus est, et accurrens cecidit super collum eius, et osculatus est eum.

verses.textEn: And the son said to him: ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. Now I am not worthy to be called your son.’
verses.textLa: Dixitque ei filius: Pater, peccavi in cælum, et coram te, iam non sum dignus vocari filius tuus.

verses.textEn: But the father said to his servants: ‘Quickly! Bring out the best robe, and clothe him with it. And put a ring on his hand and shoes on his feet.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem pater ad servos suos: Cito proferte stolam primam, et induite illum, et date annulum in manum eius, et calceamenta in pedes eius:
verses.notes: The story of the return of the Prodigal son is a prophecy in Scripture of the return of the Protestant Churches to unity with the Catholic Church. This return begins during a great famine; the famine ends only when the Protestant Churches unite with the Catholic Church. This verse, and the symbol of the ‘first robe’ indicates that the formerly-Protestant branches of the Catholic Church will have one of their members chosen as a true Pope of the Catholic Church. The symbol of the ring indicates that they will have members chosen as Bishops, and the symbol of the shoes indicates that they will have members chosen as priests and missionaries. This Pope, who will not be Roman Catholic, but will be from one of the new branches of the Catholic Church (from one of the formerly Protestant Churches), will be elected about the year 2022.

verses.textEn: And bring the fatted calf here, and kill it. And let us eat and hold a feast.
verses.textLa: et adducite vitulum saginatum, et occidite, et manducemus, et epulemur:

verses.textEn: For this son of mine was dead, and has revived; he was lost, and is found.’ And they began to feast.
verses.textLa: quia hic filius meus mortuus erat, et revixit: perierat, et inventus est. Et cœperunt epulari.

verses.textEn: But his elder son was in the field. And when he returned and drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing.
verses.textLa: Erat autem filius eius senior in agro: et cum veniret, et appropinquaret domui, audivit symphoniam, et chorum:

verses.textEn: And he called one of the servants, and he questioned him as to what these things meant.
verses.textLa: et vocavit unum de servis, et interrogavit quid hæc essent.

verses.textEn: And he said to him: ‘Your brother has returned, and your father has killed the fatted calf, because he has received him safely.’
verses.textLa: Isque dixit illi: Frater tuus venit, et occidit pater tuus vitulum saginatum, quia salvum illum recepit.

verses.textEn: Then he became indignant, and he was unwilling to enter. Therefore, his father, going out, began to plead with him.
verses.textLa: Indignatus est autem, et nolebat introire. Pater ergo illius egressus, cœpit rogare illum.

verses.textEn: And in response, he said to his father: ‘Behold, I have been serving you for so many years. And I have never transgressed your commandment. And yet, you have never given me even a young goat, so that I might feast with my friends.
verses.textLa: At ille respondens, dixit patri suo: Ecce tot annis servio tibi, et numquam mandatum tuum præterivi: et numquam dedisti mihi hœdum ut cum amicis meis epularer:

verses.textEn: Yet after this son of yours returned, who has devoured his substance with loose women, you have killed the fatted calf for him.’
verses.textLa: sed postquam filius tuus hic, qui devoravit substantiam suam cum meretricibus, venit, occidisti illi vitulum saginatum.

verses.textEn: But he said to him: ‘Son, you are with me always, and all that I have is yours.
verses.textLa: At ipse dixit illi: Fili, tu semper mecum es, et omnia mea tua sunt:

verses.textEn: But it was necessary to feast and to rejoice. For this brother of yours was dead, and has revived; he was lost, and is found.’ ”
verses.textLa: epulari autem, et gaudere oportebat, quia frater tuus hic, mortuus erat, et revixit: perierat, et inventus est.
verses.notes: In my speculative eschatology, this interaction between the elder son and the father is a prophecy in Scripture of a future Ecumenical Council, which will decide the questions of whether the Protestant Churches should have been united with the Catholic Church, and of how they should be united. The Council will decide that the unification of the Protestant Churches with the Catholic Church was necessary and just and pleasing to God.

verses.textEn: And he also said to his disciples: “A certain man was wealthy, and he had a steward of his estate. And this man was accused to him of having dissipated his goods.
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et ad discipulos suos: Homo quidam erat dives, qui habebat villicum: et hic diffamatus est apud illum quasi dissipasset bona ipsius.

verses.textEn: And he called him and said to him: ‘What is this that I hear about you? Give an account of your stewardship. For you can no longer be my steward.’
verses.textLa: Et vocavit illum, et ait illi: Quid hoc audio de te? Redde rationem villicationis tuæ: iam enim non poteris villicare.

verses.textEn: And the steward said within himself: ‘What shall I do? For my lord is taking the stewardship away from me. I am not strong enough to dig. I am too ashamed to beg.
verses.textLa: Ait autem villicus intra se: Quid faciam, quia dominus meus aufert a me villicationem, fodere non valeo, mendicare erubesco?

verses.textEn: I know what I will do so that, when I have been removed from the stewardship, they may receive me into their houses.’
verses.textLa: Scio quid faciam, ut, cum amotus fuero a villicatione, recipiant me in domos suas.

verses.textEn: And so, calling together each one of his lord’s debtors, he said to the first, ‘How much do you owe my lord?’
verses.textLa: Convocatis itaque singulis debitoribus domini sui, dicebat primo: Quantum debes domino meo?

verses.textEn: So he said, ‘One hundred jars of oil.’ And he said to him, ‘Take your invoice, and quickly, sit down and write fifty.’
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Centum cados olei. Dixitque illi: Accipe cautionem tuam: et sede cito, scribe quinquaginta.

verses.textEn: Next, he said to another, ‘In truth, how much do you owe?’ And he said, ‘One hundred measures of wheat.’ He said to him, ‘Take your record books, and write eighty.’
verses.textLa: Deinde alii dixit: Tu vero quantum debes? Qui ait: Centum coros tritici. Ait illi: Accipe litteras tuas, et scribe octoginta.

verses.textEn: And the lord praised the iniquitous steward, in that he had acted prudently. For the sons of this age are more prudent with their generation than are the sons of light.
verses.textLa: Et laudavit dominus villicum iniquitatis, quia prudenter fecisset: quia filii huius sæculi prudentiores filiis lucis in generatione sua sunt.

verses.textEn: And so I say to you, make friends for yourself using iniquitous mammon, so that, when you will have passed away, they may receive you into the eternal tabernacles.
verses.textLa: Et ego vobis dico: facite vobis amicos de mammona iniquitatis: ut, cum defeceritis, recipiant vos in æterna tabernacula.

verses.textEn: Whoever is faithful in what is least, is also faithful in what is greater. And whoever is unjust in what is small, is also unjust in what is greater.
verses.textLa: Qui fidelis est in minimo, et in maiori fidelis est: et qui in modico iniquus est, et in maiori iniquus est.

verses.textEn: So then, if you have not been faithful with iniquitous mammon, who will trust you with what is true?
verses.textLa: Si ergo in iniquo mammona fideles non fuistis: quod verum est, quis credet vobis?

verses.textEn: And if you have not been faithful with what belongs to another, who will give you what is yours?
verses.textLa: Et si in alieno fideles non fuistis: quod vestrum est, quis dabit vobis?

verses.textEn: No servant is able to serve two lords. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will cling to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon.”
verses.textLa: Nemo servus potest duobus dominis servire: aut enim unum odiet, et alterum diliget: aut uni adhærebit, et alterum contemnet: non potestis Deo servire, et mammonæ.

verses.textEn: But the Pharisees, who were greedy, were listening to all these things. And they ridiculed him.
verses.textLa: Audiebant autem omnia hæc Pharisæi, qui erant avari: et deridebant illum.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “You are the ones who justify yourselves in the sight of men. But God knows your hearts. For what is lifted up by men is an abomination in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Vos estis, qui iustificatis vos coram hominibus: Deus autem novit corda vestra: quia quod hominibus altum est, abominatio est ante Deum.

verses.textEn: The law and the prophets were until John. Since then, the kingdom of God is being evangelized, and everyone acts with violence toward it.
verses.textLa: Lex, et prophetæ usque ad Ioannem: ex eo regnum Dei evangelizatur, et omnis in illud vim facit.

verses.textEn: But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away, than for one dot of the law to fall away.
verses.textLa: Facilius est autem cælum, et terram præterire, quam de Lege unum apicem cadere.

verses.textEn: Everyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery. And whoever marries her who has been divorced by her husband commits adultery.
verses.textLa: Omnis, qui dimittit uxorem suam, et alteram ducit, mœchatur: et qui dimissam a viro ducit, mœchatur.

verses.textEn: A certain man was wealthy, and he was clothed in purple and in fine linen. And he feasted splendidly every day.
verses.textLa: Homo quidam erat dives, qui induebatur purpura, et bysso: et epulabatur quotidie splendide.

verses.textEn: And there was a certain beggar, named Lazarus, who lay at his gate, covered with sores,
verses.textLa: Et erat quidam mendicus, nomine Lazarus, qui iacebat ad ianuam eius, ulceribus plenus,

verses.textEn: wanting to be filled with the crumbs which were falling from the wealthy man’s table. But no one gave it to him. And even the dogs came and licked his sores.
verses.textLa: cupiens saturari de micis, quæ cadebant de mensa divitis, et nemo illi dabat: sed et canes veniebant, et lingebant ulcera eius.

verses.textEn: Then it happened that the beggar died, and he was carried by the Angels into the bosom of Abraham. Now the wealthy man also died, and he was entombed in Hell.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem ut moreretur mendicus, et portaretur ab Angelis in sinum Abrahæ. Mortuus est autem et dives, et sepultus est in inferno.

verses.textEn: Then lifting up his eyes, while he was in torments, he saw Abraham far away, and Lazarus in his bosom.
verses.textLa: Elevans autem oculos suos, cum esset in tormentis, vidit Abraham a longe, et Lazarum in sinu eius:

verses.textEn: And crying out, he said: ‘Father Abraham, take pity on me and send Lazarus, so that he may dip the tip of his finger in water to refresh my tongue. For I am tortured in this fire.’
verses.textLa: et ipse clamans dixit: Pater Abraham, miserere mei, et mitte Lazarum ut intingat extremum digiti sui in aquam ut refrigeret linguam meam, quia crucior in hac flamma.

verses.textEn: And Abraham said to him: ‘Son, recall that you received good things in your life, and in comparison, Lazarus received bad things. But now he is consoled, and truly you are tormented.
verses.textLa: Et dixit illi Abraham: Fili, recordare quia recepisti bona in vita tua, et Lazarus similiter mala: nunc autem hic consolatur, tu vero cruciaris.

verses.textEn: And besides all this, between us and you a great chasm has been established, so that those who might want to cross from here to you are not able, nor can someone cross from there to here.’
verses.textLa: Et in his omnibus inter nos, et vos chaos magnum firmatum est: ut hi, qui volunt hinc transire ad vos, non possint, neque inde huc transmeare.

verses.textEn: And he said: ‘Then, father, I beg you to send him to my father’s house, for I have five brothers,
verses.textLa: Et ait: Rogo ergo te pater ut mittas eum in domum patris mei.

verses.textEn: so that he may testify to them, lest they also come into this place of torments.’
verses.textLa: Habeo enim quinque fratres, ut testetur illis, ne et ipsi veniant in hunc locum tormentorum.

verses.textEn: And Abraham said to him: ‘They have Moses and the prophets. Let them listen to them.’
verses.textLa: Et ait illi Abraham: Habent Moysen, et prophetas: audiant illos.

verses.textEn: So he said: ‘No, father Abraham. But if someone were to go to them from the dead, they would repent.’
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Non, pater Abraham: sed si quis ex mortuis ierit ad eos, pœnitentiam agent.

verses.textEn: But he said to him: ‘If they will not listen to Moses and the prophets, neither will they believe even if someone has resurrected from the dead.’ ”
verses.textLa: Ait autem illi: Si Moysen, et prophetas non audiunt, neque si quis ex mortuis resurrexerit, credent.

verses.textEn: And he said to his disciples: “It is impossible for scandals not to occur. But woe to him through whom they come!
verses.textLa: Et ait ad discipulos suos: Impossibile est ut non veniant scandala: væ autem illi, per quem veniunt.

verses.textEn: It would be better for him if a millstone were placed around his neck and he were thrown into the sea, than to lead astray one of these little ones.
verses.textLa: Utilius est illi si lapis molaris imponatur circa collum eius, et proiiciatur in mare, quam ut scandalizet unum de pusillis istis.

verses.textEn: Be attentive to yourselves. If your brother has sinned against you, correct him. And if he has repented, forgive him.
verses.textLa: Attendite vobis: Si peccaverit in te frater tuus, increpa illum: et si pœnitentiam egerit, dimitte illi.

verses.textEn: And if he has sinned against you seven times a day, and seven times a day has turned back to you, saying, ‘I am sorry,’ then forgive him.”
verses.textLa: Et si septies in die peccaverit in te, et septies in die conversus fuerit ad te, dicens: Pœnitet me, dimitte illi.

verses.textEn: And the Apostles said to the Lord, “Increase our faith.”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt Apostoli Domino: Adauge nobis fidem.

verses.textEn: But the Lord said: “If you have faith like a grain of mustard seed, you may say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be uprooted, and be transplanted into the sea.’ And it would obey you.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus: Si habueritis fidem, sicut granum sinapis, dicetis huic arbori moro: Eradicare, et transplantare in mare, et obediet vobis.

verses.textEn: But which of you, having a servant plowing or feeding cattle, would say to him, as he was returning from the field, ‘Come in immediately; sit down to eat,’
verses.textLa: Quis autem vestrum habens servum arantem aut pascentem, qui regresso de agro dicat illi: Statim transi, recumbe:

verses.textEn: and would not say to him: ‘Prepare my dinner; gird yourself and minister to me, while I eat and drink; and after these things, you shall eat and drink?’
verses.textLa: et non dicat ei: Para quod cœnem, et præcinge te, et ministra mihi donec manducem et bibam, et post hæc tu manducabis, et bibes?

verses.textEn: Would he be grateful to that servant, for doing what he commanded him to do?
verses.textLa: Numquid gratiam habet servo illi, quia fecit quæ ei imperaverat?

verses.textEn: I think not. So too, when you have done all these things that have been taught to you, you should say: ‘We are useless servants. We have done what we should have done.’ ”
verses.textLa: Non puto. Sic et vos cum feceritis omnia, quæ præcepta sunt vobis, dicite: Servi inutiles sumus: quod debuimus facere, fecimus.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while he was traveling to Jerusalem, he passed through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, dum iret in Ierusalem, transibat per mediam Samariam, et Galilæam.

verses.textEn: And as he was entering a certain town, ten leprous men met him, and they stood at a distance.
verses.textLa: Et cum ingrederetur quoddam castellum, occurrerunt ei decem viri leprosi, qui steterunt a longe:

verses.textEn: And they lifted up their voice, saying, “Jesus, Teacher, take pity on us.”
verses.textLa: et levaverunt vocem, dicentes: Iesu Præceptor, miserere nostri.

verses.textEn: And when he saw them, he said, “Go, show yourselves to the priests.” And it happened that, as they were going, they were cleansed.
verses.textLa: Quos ut vidit, dixit: Ite, ostendite vos sacerdotibus. Et factum est, dum irent, mundati sunt.

verses.textEn: And one of them, when he saw that he was cleansed, returned, magnifying God with a loud voice.
verses.textLa: Unus autem ex illis, ut vidit quia mundatus est, regressus est, cum magna voce magnificans Deum,

verses.textEn: And he fell face down before his feet, giving thanks. And this one was a Samaritan.
verses.textLa: et cecidit in faciem ante pedes eius, gratias agens: et hic erat Samaritanus.

verses.textEn: And in response, Jesus said: “Were not ten made clean? And so where are the nine?
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit: Nonne decem mundati sunt? et novem ubi sunt?

verses.textEn: Was no one found who would return and give glory to God, except this foreigner?”
verses.textLa: Non est inventus qui rediret, et daret gloriam Deo, nisi hic alienigena?

verses.textEn: And he said to him: “Rise up, go forth. For your faith has saved you.”
verses.textLa: Et ait illi: Surge, vade: quia fides tua te salvum fecit.

verses.textEn: Then he was questioned by the Pharisees: “When does the kingdom of God arrive?” And in response, he said to them: “The kingdom of God arrives unobserved.
verses.textLa: Interrogatus autem a Pharisæis: Quando venit regnum Dei? respondens eis, dixit: Non venit regnum Dei cum observatione:

verses.textEn: And so, they will not say, ‘Behold, it is here,’ or ‘Behold, it is there.’ For behold, the kingdom of God is within you.”
verses.textLa: neque dicent: Ecce hic, aut ecce illic. Ecce enim regnum Dei intra vos est.

verses.textEn: And he said to his disciples: “The time will come when you will desire to see one day of the Son of man, and you will not see it.
verses.textLa: Et ait ad discipulos suos: Venient dies quando desideretis videre unum diem Filii hominis, et non videbitis.

verses.textEn: And they will say to you, ‘Behold, he is here,’ and ‘Behold, he is there.’ Do not choose to go out, and do not follow them.
verses.textLa: Et dicent vobis: Ecce hic, et ecce illic. Nolite ire, neque sectemini:

verses.textEn: For just as lightning flashes from under heaven and shines to whatever is under heaven, so also will the Son of man be in his day.
verses.textLa: nam, sicut fulgur coruscans de sub cælo in ea, quæ sub cælo sunt, fulget: ita erit Filius hominis in die sua.

verses.textEn: But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
verses.textLa: Primum autem oportet illum multa pati, et reprobari a generatione hac.

verses.textEn: And just as it happened in the days of Noah, so also will it be in the days of the Son of man.
verses.textLa: Et sicut factum est in diebus Noe, ita erit et in diebus Filii hominis.

verses.textEn: They were eating and drinking; they were taking wives and being given in marriage, even until the day that Noah entered the ark. And the flood came and destroyed them all.
verses.textLa: Edebant, et bibebant: uxores ducebant, et dabantur ad nuptias, usque in diem, qua intravit Noe in arcam: et venit diluvium, et perdidit omnes.

verses.textEn: It shall be similar to what happened in the days of Lot. They were eating and drinking; they were buying and selling; they were planting and building.
verses.textLa: Similiter sicut factum est in diebus Lot: Edebant, et bibebant: emebant, et vendebant: plantabant, et ædificabant:

verses.textEn: Then, on the day that Lot departed from Sodom, it rained fire and brimstone from heaven, and it destroyed them all.
verses.textLa: qua die autem exiit Lot a Sodomis, pluit ignem, et sulphur de cælo, et omnes perdidit:

verses.textEn: According to these things, so shall it be in the day when the Son of man will be revealed.
verses.textLa: secundum hæc erit qua die Filius hominis revelabitur.

verses.textEn: In that hour, whoever will be on the rooftop, with his goods in the house, let him not descend to take them. And whoever will be in the field, similarly, let him not turn back.
verses.textLa: In illa hora qui fuerit in tecto, et vasa eius in domo, ne descendat tollere illa: et qui in agro, similiter non redeat retro.

verses.textEn: Remember Lot’s wife.
verses.textLa: Memores estote uxoris Lot.

verses.textEn: Whoever has sought to save his life, will lose it; and whoever has lost it, will bring it back to life.
verses.textLa: Quicumque quæsierit animam suam salvam facere, perdet illam: et quicumque perdiderit illam, vivificabit eam.
verses.notes: The word ‘vivificabit’ does not mean ‘to preserve’, but ‘to bring back to life.’

verses.textEn: I say to you, in that night, there will be two in one bed. One will be taken up, and the other will be left behind.
verses.textLa: Dico vobis: in illa nocte erunt duo in lecto uno: unus assumetur, et alter relinquetur:

verses.textEn: Two will be at the grindstone together. One will be taken up, and the other will be left behind. Two will be in the field. One will be taken up, and the other will be left behind.”
verses.textLa: duæ erunt molentes in unum: una assumetur, et altera relinquetur: duo in agro: unus assumetur, et alter relinquetur.

verses.textEn: Responding, they said to him, “Where, Lord?”
verses.textLa: Respondentes dicunt illi: Ubi Domine?

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “Wherever the body will be, in that place also, the eagles shall be gathered together.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit illis: Ubicumque fuerit corpus, illuc congregabuntur et aquilæ.
verses.notes: The word ‘aquilae’ is clearly eagles, and not vultures.

verses.textEn: Now he also told them a parable, that we should continually pray and not cease,
verses.textLa: Dicebat autem et parabolam ad illos, quoniam oportet semper orare et non deficere,

verses.textEn: saying: “There was a certain judge in a certain city, who did not fear God and did not respect man.
verses.textLa: dicens: Iudex quidam erat in quadam civitate, qui Deum non timebat, et hominem non reverebatur.

verses.textEn: But there was a certain widow in that city, and she went to him, saying, ‘Vindicate me from my adversary.’
verses.textLa: Vidua autem quædam erat in civitate illa, et veniebat ad eum, dicens: Vindica me de adversario meo.

verses.textEn: And he refused to do so for a long time. But afterwards, he said within himself: ‘Even though I do not fear God, nor respect man,
verses.textLa: Et nolebat per multum tempus. Post hæc autem dixit intra se: Etsi Deum non timeo, nec hominem revereor:

verses.textEn: yet because this widow is pestering me, I will vindicate her, lest by returning, she may, in the end, wear me out.’ ”
verses.textLa: tamen quia molesta est mihi hæc vidua, vindicabo illam, ne in novissimo veniens sugillet me.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said: “Listen to what the unjust judge said.
verses.textLa: Ait autem Dominus: Audite quid iudex iniquitatis dicit:

verses.textEn: So then, will not God grant the vindication of his elect, who cry out to him day and night? Or will he continue to endure them?
verses.textLa: Deus autem non faciet vindictam electorum suorum clamantium ad se die ac nocte, et patientiam habebit in illis?
verses.notes: This last part is not saying that God is patient. It is a common error among translators to interpret an obscure verse as having a meaning that is uninformative and excessively simplified, rather than to clarify the true meaning of the verse, or to leave it obscure. We already know that God is patient. The point of the parable is not that God is patient, but rather that, if you pester God enough for something, He will give it to you, rather than continue to endure your complaints.

verses.textEn: I tell you that he will quickly bring vindication to them. Yet truly, when the Son of man returns, do you think that he will find faith on earth?”
verses.textLa: Dico vobis quia cito faciet vindictam illorum. Verumtamen Filius hominis veniens, putas, inveniet fidem in terra?

verses.textEn: Now about certain persons who consider themselves to be just, while disdaining others, he told also this parable:
verses.textLa: Dixit autem et ad quosdam, qui in se confidebant tamquam iusti, et aspernabantur ceteros, parabolam istam:

verses.textEn: “Two men ascended to the temple, in order to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a tax collector.
verses.textLa: Duo homines ascenderunt in templum ut orarent: unus Pharisæus, et alter publicanus.

verses.textEn: Standing, the Pharisee prayed within himself in this way: ‘O God, I give thanks to you that I am not like the rest of men: robbers, unjust, adulterers, even as this tax collector chooses to be.
verses.textLa: Pharisæus stans, hæc apud se orabat: Deus gratias ago tibi, quia non sum sicut ceteri hominum: raptores, iniusti, adulteri: velut etiam hic publicanus.

verses.textEn: I fast twice between Sabbaths. I give tithes from all that I possess.’
verses.textLa: Ieiuno bis in Sabbato: decimas do omnium, quæ possideo.

verses.textEn: And the tax collector, standing at a distance, was not willing to even lift up his eyes to heaven. But he struck his chest, saying: ‘O God, be merciful to me, a sinner.’
verses.textLa: Et publicanus a longe stans, nolebat nec oculos ad cælum levare: sed percutiebat pectus suum, dicens: Deus propitius esto mihi peccatori.

verses.textEn: I say to you, this one descended to his house justified, but not the other. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled; and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.”
verses.textLa: Dico vobis, descendit hic iustificatus in domum suam ab illo, quia omnis, qui se exaltat, humiliabitur: et qui se humiliat, exaltabitur.

verses.textEn: And they were bringing little children to him, so that he might touch them. And when the disciples saw this, they rebuked them.
verses.textLa: Afferebant autem ad illum et infantes, ut eos tangeret. Quod cum viderent discipuli, increpabant illos.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, calling them together, said: “Allow the children to come to me, and do not be an obstacle to them. For of such is the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem convocans illos, dixit: Sinite pueros venire ad me, et nolite vetare eos. Talium est enim regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: Amen, I say to you, whoever will not accept the kingdom of God like a child, will not enter into it.”
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis: Quicumque non acceperit regnum Dei sicut puer, non intrabit in illud.

verses.textEn: And a certain leader questioned him, saying: “Good teacher, what should I do to possess eternal life?”
verses.textLa: Et interrogavit eum quidam princeps, dicens: Magister bone, quid faciens vitam æternam possidebo?

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to him: “Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ei Iesus: Quid me dicis bonum? nemo bonus nisi solus Deus.

verses.textEn: You know the commandments: You shall not kill. You shall not commit adultery. You shall not steal. You shall not give false testimony. Honor your father and mother.”
verses.textLa: Mandata nosti: Non occides: Non mœchaberis: Non furtum facies: Non falsum testimonium dices: Honora patrem tuum, et matrem.

verses.textEn: And he said, “I have kept all these things from my youth.”
verses.textLa: Qui ait: Hæc omnia custodivi a iuventute mea.

verses.textEn: And when Jesus heard this, he said to him: “One thing is still lacking for you. Sell all the things that you have, and give to the poor. And then you will have treasure in heaven. And come, follow me.”
verses.textLa: Quo audito, Iesus ait ei: Adhuc unum tibi deest: omnia quæcumque habes vende, et da pauperibus, et habebis thesaurum in cælo: et veni, sequere me.
verses.notes: Those who follow Jesus by being ordained should be men who have kept all the commandments from their youth.

verses.textEn: When he heard this, he became very sorrowful. For he was very rich.
verses.textLa: His ille auditis, contristatus est: quia dives erat valde.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, seeing him brought to sorrow, said: “How difficult it is for those who have money to enter into the kingdom of God!
verses.textLa: Videns autem Iesus illum tristem factum, dixit: Quam difficile, qui pecunias habent, in regnum Dei intrabunt!

verses.textEn: For it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle, than for a wealthy man to enter into the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Facilius est enim camelum per foramen acus transire, quam divitem intrare in regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: And those who were listening to this said, “Then who is able to be saved?”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt qui audiebant: Et quis potest salvus fieri?

verses.textEn: He said to them, “Things that are impossible with men are possible with God.”
verses.textLa: Ait illis: Quæ impossibilia sunt apud homines, possibilia sunt apud Deum.

verses.textEn: And Peter said, “Behold, we have left everything, and we have followed you.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem Petrus: Ecce nos dimisimus omnia et secuti sumus te.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Amen, I say to you, there is no one who has left behind home, or parents, or brothers, or a wife, or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
verses.textLa: Qui dixit eis: Amen dico vobis, nemo est, qui reliquit domum, aut parentes, aut fratres, aut uxorem, aut filios propter regnum Dei,

verses.textEn: who will not receive much more in this time, and in the age to come eternal life.”
verses.textLa: et non recipiat multo plura in hoc tempore, et in sæculo venturo vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus took the twelve aside, and he said to them: “Behold, we are ascending to Jerusalem, and everything shall be completed which was written by the prophets about the Son of man.
verses.textLa: Assumpsit autem Iesus duodecim, et ait illis: Ecce ascendimus Ierosolymam, et consummabuntur omnia, quæ scripta sunt per prophetas de Filio hominis.

verses.textEn: For he will be handed over to the Gentiles, and he will be mocked and scourged and spit upon.
verses.textLa: Tradetur enim Gentibus, et illudetur, et flagellabitur, et conspuetur:

verses.textEn: And after they have scourged him, they will kill him. And on the third day, he will rise again.”
verses.textLa: et postquam flagellaverint, occident eum, et tertia die resurget.

verses.textEn: But they understood none of these things. For this word was concealed from them, and they did not understand the things that were said.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi nihil horum intellexerunt, et erat verbum istud absconditum ab eis, et non intelligebant quæ dicebantur.

verses.textEn: Now it happened that, as he was approaching Jericho, a certain blind man was sitting beside the way, begging.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, cum appropinquaret Iericho, cæcus quidam sedebat secus viam, mendicans.

verses.textEn: And when he heard the multitude passing by, he asked what this was.
verses.textLa: Et cum audiret turbam prætereuntem, interrogabat quid hoc esset.

verses.textEn: And they told him that Jesus of Nazareth was passing by.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt autem ei, quod Iesus Nazarenus transiret.

verses.textEn: And he cried out, saying, “Jesus, Son of David, take pity on me!”
verses.textLa: Et clamavit, dicens: Iesu fili David miserere mei.

verses.textEn: And those who were passing by rebuked him, so that he would be silent. Yet truly, he cried out all the more, “Son of David, take pity on me!”
verses.textLa: Et qui præibant, increpabant eum ut taceret. Ipse vero multo magis clamabat: Fili David miserere mei.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus, standing still, ordered him to be brought to him. And when he had drawn near, he questioned him,
verses.textLa: Stans autem Iesus iussit illum adduci ad se. Et cum appropinquasset, interrogavit illum,

verses.textEn: saying, “What do you want, that I might do for you?” So he said, “Lord, that I may see.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Quid tibi vis faciam? At ille dixit: Domine ut videam.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to him: “Look around. Your faith has saved you.”
verses.textLa: Et Iesus dixit illi: Respice, fides tua te salvum fecit.

verses.textEn: And immediately he saw. And he followed him, magnifying God. And all the people, when they saw this, gave praise to God.
verses.textLa: Et confestim vidit, et sequebatur illum magnificans Deum. Et omnis plebs ut vidit, dedit laudem Deo.

verses.textEn: And having entered, he walked through Jericho.
verses.textLa: Et ingressus perambulabat Iericho.

verses.textEn: And behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus. And he was the leader of the tax collectors, and he was wealthy.
verses.textLa: Et ecce vir nomine Zachæus: et hic princeps erat publicanorum, et ipse dives:

verses.textEn: And he sought to see Jesus, to see who he was. But he was unable to do so, because of the crowd, for he was small in stature.
verses.textLa: et quærebat videre Iesum, quis esset: et non poterat præ turba, quia statura pusillus erat.

verses.textEn: And running ahead, he climbed up a sycamore tree, so that he might see him. For he was to pass near there.
verses.textLa: Et præcurrens ascendit in arborem sycomorum ut videret eum: quia inde erat transiturus.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the place, Jesus looked up and saw him, and he said to him: “Zacchaeus, hurry down. For today, I should lodge in your house.”
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset ad locum, suspiciens Iesus vidit illum, et dixit ad eum: Zachæe festinans descende: quia hodie in domo tua oportet me manere.

verses.textEn: And hurrying, he came down, and he received him joyfully.
verses.textLa: Et festinans descendit, et excepit illum gaudens.

verses.textEn: And when they all saw this, they murmured, saying that he had turned aside to a sinful man.
verses.textLa: Et cum viderent omnes, murmurabant, dicentes quod ad hominem peccatorem divertisset.

verses.textEn: But Zacchaeus, standing still, said to the Lord: “Behold, Lord, one half of my goods I give to the poor. And if I have cheated anyone in any matter, I will repay him fourfold.”
verses.textLa: Stans autem Zachæus, dixit ad Dominum: Ecce dimidium bonorum meorum, Domine, do pauperibus: et si quid aliquem defraudavi, reddo quadruplum.

verses.textEn: Jesus said to him: “Today, salvation has come to this house; because of this, he too is a son of Abraham.
verses.textLa: Ait Iesus ad eum: Quia hodie salus domui huic facta est: eo quod et ipse filius sit Abrahæ.

verses.textEn: For the Son of man has come to seek and to save what had been lost.”
verses.textLa: Venit enim Filius hominis quærere, et salvum facere quod perierat.

verses.textEn: As they were listening to these things, continuing on, he spoke a parable, because he was nearing Jerusalem, and because they guessed that the kingdom of God might be manifested without delay.
verses.textLa: Hæc illis audientibus adiiciens, dixit parabolam, eo quod esset prope Ierusalem: et quia existimarent quod confestim regnum Dei manifestaretur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he said: “A certain man of nobility traveled to a far away region, to receive for himself a kingdom, and to return.
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo: Homo quidam nobilis abiit in regionem longinquam accipere sibi regnum, et reverti.

verses.textEn: And calling his ten servants, he gave them ten pounds, and he said to them: ‘Do business until I return.’
verses.textLa: Vocatis autem decem servis suis, dedit eis decem mnas, et ait ad illos: Negotiamini dum venio.
verses.notes: One mina (mna) weighed just over one pound.

verses.textEn: But his citizens hated him. And so they sent a delegation after him, saying, ‘We do not want this one to reign over us.’
verses.textLa: Cives autem eius oderant eum: et miserunt legationem post illum, dicentes: Nolumus hunc regnare super nos.

verses.textEn: And it happened that he returned, having received the kingdom. And he ordered the servants, to whom he had given the money, to be called so that he would know how much each one had earned by doing business.
verses.textLa: Et factum est ut rediret accepto regno: et iussit vocari servos, quibus dedit pecuniam, ut sciret quantum quisque negotiatus esset.

verses.textEn: Now the first approached, saying: ‘Lord, your one pound has earned ten pounds.’
verses.textLa: Venit autem primus dicens: Domine, mna tua decem mnas acquisivit.

verses.textEn: And he said to him: ‘Well done, good servant. Since you have been faithful in a small matter, you will hold authority over ten cities.’
verses.textLa: Et ait illi: Euge bone serve, quia in modico fuisti fidelis, eris potestatem habens super decem civitates.

verses.textEn: And the second came, saying: ‘Lord, your one pound has earned five pounds.’
verses.textLa: Et alter venit, dicens: Domine, mna tua fecit quinque mnas.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, ‘And so, you shall be over five cities.’
verses.textLa: Et huic ait: Et tu esto super quinque civitates.

verses.textEn: And another approached, saying: ‘Lord, behold your one pound, which I kept stored in a cloth.
verses.textLa: Et alter venit, dicens: Domine, ecce mna tua, quam habui repositam in sudario:

verses.textEn: For I feared you, because you are an austere man. You take up what you did not lay down, and you reap what you did not sow.’
verses.textLa: timui enim te, quia homo austerus es: tollis quod non posuisti, et metis quod non seminasti.

verses.textEn: He said to him: ‘By your own mouth, do I judge you, O wicked servant. You knew that I am an austere man, taking up what I did not lay down, and reaping what I did not sow.
verses.textLa: Dicit ei: De ore tuo te iudico serve nequam. Sciebas quod ego homo austerus sum, tollens quod non posui, et metens quod non seminavi:

verses.textEn: And so, why did you not give my money to the bank, so that, upon my return, I might have withdrawn it with interest?’
verses.textLa: et quare non dedisti pecuniam meam ad mensam, ut ego veniens cum usuris utique exegissem illam?

verses.textEn: And he said to the bystanders, ‘Take the pound away from him, and give it to him who has ten pounds.’
verses.textLa: Et astantibus dixit: Auferte ab illo mnam, et date illi, qui decem mnas habet.

verses.textEn: And they said to him, ‘Lord, he has ten pounds.’
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt ei: Domine, habet decem mnas.

verses.textEn: So then, I say to you, that to all who have, it shall be given, and he will have in abundance. And from him who does not have, even what he has will be taken from him.
verses.textLa: Dico autem vobis, quia omni habenti dabitur, et abundabit: ab eo autem, qui non habet, et quod habet auferetur ab eo.

verses.textEn: ‘Yet truly, as for those enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here, and put them to death before me.’ ”
verses.textLa: Verumtamen inimicos meos illos, qui noluerunt me regnare super se, adducite huc: et interficite ante me.

verses.textEn: And having said these things, he went ahead, ascending to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et his dictis, præcedebat ascendens Ierosolymam.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when he had drawn near to Bethphage and Bethania, to the mount which is called Olivet, he sent two of his disciples,
verses.textLa: Et factum est, cum appropinquasset ad Bethphage, et Bethaniam ad montem, qui vocatur Oliveti, misit duos discipulos suos,

verses.textEn: saying: “Go into the town which is opposite you. Upon entering it, you will find the colt of a donkey, tied, on which no man has ever sat. Untie it, and lead it here.
verses.textLa: dicens: Ite in castellum, quod contra est: in quod introeuntes, invenietis pullum asinæ alligatum, cui nemo umquam hominum sedit: solvite illum, et adducite.

verses.textEn: And if anyone will ask you, ‘Why are you untying it?’ you shall say this to him: ‘Because the Lord has requested its service.’ ”
verses.textLa: Et si quis vos interrogaverit: Quare solvitis? sic dicetis ei: Quia Dominus operam eius desiderat.
verses.notes: This is an example of the doctrine of expropriation, in which goods belonging to another can be taken, in some cases of need, without stealing, because all goods belong first and foremost to the Lord.

verses.textEn: And those who were sent went out, and they found the colt standing, just as he told them.
verses.textLa: Abierunt autem qui missi erant: et invenerunt, sicut dixit illis, stantem pullum.

verses.textEn: Then, as they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
verses.textLa: Solventibus autem illis pullum, dixerunt domini eius ad illos: Quid solvitis pullum?

verses.textEn: So they said, “Because the Lord has need of it.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Quia Dominus eum necessarium habet.

verses.textEn: And they led it to Jesus. And casting their garments on the colt, they helped Jesus onto it.
verses.textLa: Et duxerunt illum ad Iesum. Et iacentes vestimenta sua supra pullum, imposuerunt Iesum.

verses.textEn: Then, as he was traveling, they were laying down their garments along the way.
verses.textLa: Eunte autem illo, substernebant vestimenta sua in via.

verses.textEn: And when he was now drawing near to the descent of Mount Olivet, the entire crowd of his disciples began to praise God joyfully, with a loud voice, over all the powerful works which they had seen,
verses.textLa: Et cum appropinquaret iam ad descensum Montis Oliveti, cœperunt omnes turbæ discipulorum gaudentes laudare Deum voce magna super omnibus, quas viderant, virtutibus,

verses.textEn: saying: “Blessed is the king who has arrived in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory on high!”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Benedictus, qui venit rex in nomine Domini! Pax in cælo, et gloria in excelsis!

verses.textEn: And certain Pharisees within the crowd said to him, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples.”
verses.textLa: Et quidam Pharisæorum de turbis, dixerunt ad illum: Magister, increpa discipulos tuos.

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “I tell you, that if these will keep silent, the stones themselves will cry out.”
verses.textLa: Quibus ipse ait: Dico vobis, quia si hi tacuerint, lapides clamabunt.

verses.textEn: And when he drew near, seeing the city, he wept over it, saying:
verses.textLa: Et ut appropinquavit, videns civitatem flevit super illam, dicens:

verses.textEn: “If only you had known, indeed even in this your day, which things are for your peace. But now they are hidden from your eyes.
verses.textLa: Quia si cognovisses et tu, et quidem in hac die tua, quæ ad pacem tibi, nunc autem abscondita sunt ab oculis tuis.

verses.textEn: For the days will overtake you. And your enemies will encircle you with a valley. And they will surround you and hem you in on every side.
verses.textLa: Quia venient dies in te: et circumdabunt te inimici tui vallo, et circumdabunt te: et coangustabunt te undique:

verses.textEn: And they will knock you down to the ground, with your sons who are in you. And they will not leave stone upon stone within you, because you did not recognize the time of your visitation.”
verses.textLa: et ad terram prosternent te, et filios tuos, qui in te sunt, et non relinquent in te lapidem super lapidem: eo quod non cognoveris tempus visitationis tuæ.

verses.textEn: And entering into the temple, he began to cast out those who sold in it, and those who bought,
verses.textLa: Et ingressus in templum, cœpit eiicere vendentes in illo, et ementes,

verses.textEn: saying to them: “It is written: ‘My house is a house of prayer.’ But you have made it into a den of robbers.”
verses.textLa: dicens illis: Scriptum est: Quia domus mea domus orationis est. Vos autem fecistis illam speluncam latronum.

verses.textEn: And he was teaching in the temple daily. And the leaders of the priests, and the scribes, and the leaders of the people were seeking to destroy him.
verses.textLa: Et erat docens quotidie in templo. Principes autem sacerdotum, et scribæ, et princeps plebis quærebant illum perdere:

verses.textEn: But they could not find what to do to him. For all the people were listening to him attentively.
verses.textLa: et non inveniebant quid facerent illi. Omnis enim populus suspensus erat, audiens illum.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, on one of the days when he was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the Gospel, the leaders of the priests, and the scribes, gathered together with the elders,
verses.textLa: Et factum est in una dierum, docente illo populum in templo, et evangelizante, convenerunt principes sacerdotum, et scribæ cum senioribus,

verses.textEn: and they spoke to him, saying: “Tell us, by what authority do you do these things? Or, who is it that has given you this authority?”
verses.textLa: et aiunt dicentes ad illum: Dic nobis, in qua potestate hæc facis? aut: Quis est, qui dedit tibi hanc potestatem?

verses.textEn: And in response, Jesus said to them: “I will also question you about one word. Respond to me:
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit ad illos: Interrogabo vos et ego unum verbum. Respondete mihi:

verses.textEn: The baptism of John, was it from heaven, or of men?”
verses.textLa: Baptismus Ioannis de cælo erat, an ex hominibus?

verses.textEn: So they discussed it among themselves, saying: “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will say, ‘Then why did you not believe him?’
verses.textLa: At illi cogitabant intra se, dicentes: Quia si dixerimus, de cælo, dicet: Quare ergo non credidistis illi?

verses.textEn: But if we say, ‘Of men,’ the whole people will stone us. For they are certain that John was a prophet.”
verses.textLa: Si autem dixerimus, Ex hominibus, plebs universa lapidabit nos: certi sunt enim, Ioannem prophetam esse.

verses.textEn: And so they responded that they did not know where it was from.
verses.textLa: Et responderunt se nescire unde esset.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”
verses.textLa: Et Iesus ait illis: Neque ego dico vobis in qua potestate hæc facio.

verses.textEn: Then he began to tell the people this parable: “A man planted a vineyard, and he loaned it to settlers, and he was on a sojourn for a long time.
verses.textLa: Cœpit autem dicere ad plebem parabolam hanc: Homo plantavit vineam, et locavit eam colonis: et ipse peregre fuit multis temporibus.

verses.textEn: And in due time, he sent a servant to the farmers, so that they would give to him from the fruit of the vineyard. And they beat him and drove him away, empty-handed.
verses.textLa: Et in tempore misit ad cultores servum, ut de fructu vineæ darent illi. Qui cæsum dimiserunt eum inanem.
