verses.textEn: And he continued to send another servant. But beating him and treating him with contempt, they likewise sent him away, empty-handed.
verses.textLa: Et addidit alterum servum mittere. Illi autem hunc quoque cædentes, et afficientes contumelia, dimiserunt inanem.

verses.textEn: And he continued to send a third. And wounding him also, they drove him away.
verses.textLa: Et addidit tertium mittere: qui et illum vulnerantes eiecerunt.

verses.textEn: Then the lord of the vineyard said: ‘What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Perhaps when they have seen him, they will respect him.’
verses.textLa: Dixit autem dominus vineæ: Quid faciam? Mittam filium meum dilectum: forsitan, cum hunc viderint, verebuntur.

verses.textEn: And when the settlers had seen him, they discussed it among themselves, saying: ‘This one is the heir. Let us kill him, so that the inheritance will be ours.’
verses.textLa: Quem cum vidissent coloni, cogitaverunt intra se, dicentes: Hic est heres, occidamus illum, ut nostra fiat hereditas.

verses.textEn: And forcing him outside of the vineyard, they killed him. What, then, will the lord of the vineyard do to them?”
verses.textLa: Et eiectum illum extra vineam, occiderunt. Quid ergo faciet illis dominus vineæ?

verses.textEn: “He will come and destroy those settlers, and he will give the vineyard to others.” And upon hearing this, they said to him, “Let it not be.”
verses.textLa: Veniet, et perdet colonos istos, et dabit vineam aliis. Quo audito, dixerunt illi: Absit.
verses.notes: The word ‘absit’ (let it not be, or far be it) is basically the opposite of the word ‘fiat’ (let it be, or, so be it).

verses.textEn: Then, gazing at them, he said: “Then what does this mean, which is written: ‘The stone which the builders have rejected, the same has become the head of the corner?’
verses.textLa: Ille autem aspiciens eos ait: Quid est ergo hoc, quod scriptum est: Lapidem, quem reprobaverunt ædificantes, hic factus est in caput anguli?

verses.textEn: Everyone who falls on that stone will be shattered. And anyone upon whom it falls will be crushed.”
verses.textLa: Omnis, qui ceciderit super illum lapidem, conquassabitur: super quem autem ceciderit, comminuet illum.

verses.textEn: And the leaders of the priests, and the scribes, were seeking to lay hands on him in that same hour, but they feared the people. For they realized that he had spoken this parable about them.
verses.textLa: Et quærebant principes sacerdotum, et scribæ mittere in illum manus illa hora: et timuerunt populum: cognoverunt enim quod ad ipsos dixerit similitudinem hanc.

verses.textEn: And being attentive, they sent traitors, who would pretend that they were just, so that they might catch him in his words and then hand him over to the power and authority of the procurator.
verses.textLa: Et observantes miserunt insidiatores, qui se iustos simularent, ut caparent eum in sermone, ut traderent illum principatui, et potestati præsidis.

verses.textEn: And they questioned him, saying: “Teacher, we know that you speak and teach correctly, and that you do not consider anyone’s status, but you teach the way of God in truth.
verses.textLa: Et interrogaverunt eum, dicentes: Magister, scimus quia recte dicis, et doces: et non accipis personam, sed viam Dei in veritate doces:

verses.textEn: Is it lawful for us to pay the tribute to Caesar, or not?”
verses.textLa: licet nobis tributum dare Cæsari, an non?

verses.textEn: But realizing their deceitfulness, he said to them: “Why do you test me?
verses.textLa: Considerans autem dolum illorum, dixit ad eos: Quid me tentatis?

verses.textEn: Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?” In response, they said to him, “Caesar’s.”
verses.textLa: Ostendite mihi denarium: Cuius habet imaginem, et inscriptionem? Respondentes dixerunt ei: Cæsaris.

verses.textEn: And so, he said to them: “Then repay the things that are Caesar’s, to Caesar, and the things that are God’s, to God.”
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Reddite ergo quæ sunt Cæsaris, Cæsari: et quæ sunt Dei, Deo.

verses.textEn: And they were not able to contradict his word before the people. And being amazed at his answer, they were silent.
verses.textLa: Et non potuerunt verbum eius reprehendere coram plebe: et mirati in responso eius, tacuerunt.

verses.textEn: Now some of the Sadducees, who deny that there is a resurrection, approached him. And they questioned him,
verses.textLa: Accesserunt autem quidam Sadducæorum, qui negant esse resurrectionem, et interrogaverunt eum,

verses.textEn: saying: “Teacher, Moses wrote for us: If any man’s brother will have died, having a wife, and if he does not have any children, then his brother should take her as his wife, and he should raise up offspring for his brother.
verses.textLa: dicentes: Magister, Moyses scripsit nobis: Si frater alicuius mortuus fuerit habens uxorem, et hic sine liberis fuerit, ut accipiat eam frater eius uxorem, et suscitet semen fratri suo:

verses.textEn: And so there were seven brothers. And the first took a wife, and he died without sons.
verses.textLa: septem ergo fratres erant: et primus accepit uxorem, et mortuus est sine filiis.

verses.textEn: And the next one married her, and he also died without a son.
verses.textLa: Et sequens accepit illam, et ipse mortuus est sine filio.
verses.notes: The bearing of male offspring was desired because lineage in ancient Judaism was through the male line. So, to carry on the brother’s name, a male offspring would be needed.

verses.textEn: And the third married her, and similarly all seven, and none of them left behind any offspring, and they each died.
verses.textLa: Et tertius accepit illam. Similiter et omnes septem, et non reliquerunt semen, et mortui sunt.

verses.textEn: Last of all, the woman also died.
verses.textLa: Novissime omnium mortua est et mulier.

verses.textEn: In the resurrection, then, whose wife will she be? For certainly all seven had her as a wife.”
verses.textLa: In resurrectione ergo, cuius eorum erit uxor? Siquidem septem habuerunt eam uxorem.

verses.textEn: And so, Jesus said to them: “The children of this age marry and are given in marriage.
verses.textLa: Et ait illis Iesus: Filii huius sæculi nubunt, et traduntur ad nuptias:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, those who shall be held worthy of that age, and of the resurrection from the dead, will neither be married, nor take wives.
verses.textLa: illi vero qui digni habebuntur sæculo illo, et resurrectione ex mortuis, neque nubent, neque ducent uxores:
verses.notes: In other words, they will not still be married after death and resurrection, nor will they marry anew.

verses.textEn: For they can no longer die. For they are equal to the Angels, and they are children of God, since they are children of the resurrection.
verses.textLa: neque enim ultra mori potuerunt: æquales enim Angelis sunt, et filii sunt Dei: cum sint filii resurrectionis.

verses.textEn: For in truth, the dead do rise again, as Moses also showed beside the bush, when he called the Lord: ‘The God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’
verses.textLa: Quia vero resurgant mortui, et Moyses ostendit secus rubum, sicut dicit Dominum, Deum Abraham, et Deum Isaac, et Deum Iacob.

verses.textEn: And so he is not the God of the dead, but of the living. For all are alive to him.”
verses.textLa: Deus autem non est mortuorum, sed vivorum: omnes enim vivunt ei.

verses.textEn: Then some of the scribes, in response, said to him, “Teacher, you have spoken well.”
verses.textLa: Respondentes autem quidam scribarum, dixerunt ei: Magister, bene dixisti.

verses.textEn: And they no longer dared to question him about anything.
verses.textLa: Et amplius non audebant eum quidquam interrogare.

verses.textEn: But he said to them: “How can they say that the Christ is the son of David?
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ad illos: Quomodo dicunt Christum, filium esse David?

verses.textEn: Even David himself says, in the book of Psalms: ‘The Lord said to my Lord, sit at my right hand,
verses.textLa: Et ipse David dicit in libro Psalmorum: Dixit Dominus Domino meo, sede a dextris meis,

verses.textEn: until I set your enemies as your footstool.’
verses.textLa: donec ponam inimicos tuos, scabellum pedum tuorum?

verses.textEn: Therefore, David calls him Lord. So how can he be his son?”
verses.textLa: David ergo Dominum illum vocat: et quomodo filius eius est?

verses.textEn: Now in the hearing of all the people, he said to his disciples:
verses.textLa: Audiente autem omni populo, dixit discipulis suis:

verses.textEn: “Be cautious of the scribes, who choose to walk in long robes, and who love greetings in the marketplace, and the first chairs in the synagogues, and the first places at table during feasts,
verses.textLa: Attendite a scribis, qui volunt ambulare in stolis, et amant salutationes in foro, et primas cathedras in synagogis, et primos discubitus in conviviis:

verses.textEn: who devour the houses of widows, feigning long prayers. These will receive the greater damnation.”
verses.textLa: qui devorant domos viduarum, simulantes longam orationem. Hi accipient damnationem maiorem.

verses.textEn: And looking around, he saw the wealthy putting their donations into the offertory.
verses.textLa: Respiciens autem vidit eos, qui mittebant munera sua in gazophylacium, divites.

verses.textEn: Then he also saw a certain widow, a pauper, putting in two small brass coins.
verses.textLa: Vidit autem et quamdam viduam pauperculam mittentem æra minuta duo.

verses.textEn: And he said: “Truly, I say to you, that this poor widow has put in more than all the others.
verses.textLa: Et dixit: Vere dico vobis, quia vidua hæc pauper, plus quam omnes misit.

verses.textEn: For all these, out of their abundance, have added to the gifts for God. But she, out of what she needed, has put in all that she had to live on.”
verses.textLa: Nam omnes hi ex abundanti sibi miserunt in munera Dei: hæc autem ex eo, quod deest illi, omnem victum suum, quem habuit, misit.

verses.textEn: And when some of them were saying, about the temple, that it was adorned with excellent stones and gifts, he said,
verses.textLa: Et quibusdam dicentibus de templo quod bonis lapidibus, et donis ornatum esset, dixit:

verses.textEn: “These things that you see, the days will arrive when there will not be left behind stone upon stone, which is not thrown down.”
verses.textLa: Hæc, quæ videtis, venient dies, in quibus non relinquetur lapis super lapidem, qui non destruatur.

verses.textEn: Then they questioned him, saying: “Teacher, when will these things be? And what will be the sign when these things will happen?”
verses.textLa: Interrogaverunt autem illum, dicentes: Præceptor, quando hæc erunt, et quod signum cum fieri incipient?

verses.textEn: And he said: “Be cautious, lest you be seduced. For many will come in my name, saying: ‘For I am he,’ and, ‘The time has drawn near.’ And so, do not choose to go after them.
verses.textLa: Qui dixit: Videte ne seducamini: multi enim venient in nomine meo, dicentes quia ego sum: et tempus appropinquavit: nolite ergo ire post eos.

verses.textEn: And when you will have heard of battles and seditions, do not be terrified. These things must happen first. But the end is not so soon.”
verses.textLa: Cum autem audieritis prælia, et seditiones, nolite terreri: oportet primum hæc fieri, sed nondum statim finis.

verses.textEn: Then he said to them: “People will rise up against people, and kingdom against kingdom.
verses.textLa: Tunc dicebat illis: Surget gens contra gentem, et regnum adversus regnum.

verses.textEn: And there will be great earthquakes in various places, and pestilences, and famines, and terrors from heaven; and there will be great signs.
verses.textLa: Et terræmotus magni erunt per loca, et pestilentiæ, et fames, terroresque de cælo, et signa magna erunt.
verses.notes: These two phrases, ‘terrors from heaven’ and ‘great signs,’ indicate that some of these signs will be supernatural in origin; these signs are not merely natural disasters or increases in the usual sufferings that the world endures.

verses.textEn: But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, handing you over to synagogues and into custody, dragging you before kings and governors, because of my name.
verses.textLa: Sed ante hæc omnia iniicient vobis manus suas, et persequentur tradentes in synagogas, et custodias, trahentes ad reges, et præsides propter nomen meum:

verses.textEn: And this will be an opportunity for you to give testimony.
verses.textLa: continget autem vobis in testimonium.

verses.textEn: Therefore, set this in your hearts: that you should not consider in advance how you might respond.
verses.textLa: Ponite ergo in cordibus vestris non præmeditari quemadmodum respondeatis.

verses.textEn: For I will give to you a mouth and wisdom, which all your adversaries will not be able to resist or contradict.
verses.textLa: Ego enim dabo vobis os, et sapientiam, cui non poterunt resistere, et contradicere omnes adversarii vestri.

verses.textEn: And you will be handed over by your parents, and brothers, and relatives, and friends. And they will bring about the death of some of you.
verses.textLa: Trademini autem a parentibus, et fratribus, et cognatis, et amicis, et morte afficient ex vobis:

verses.textEn: And you will be hated by all because of my name.
verses.textLa: et eritis odio omnibus propter nomen meum:

verses.textEn: And yet, not a hair of your head will perish.
verses.textLa: et capillus de capite vestro non peribit.

verses.textEn: By your patience, you shall possess your souls.
verses.textLa: In patientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras.

verses.textEn: Then, when you will have seen Jerusalem encircled by an army, know then that its desolation has drawn near.
verses.textLa: Cum autem videritis circumdari ab exercitu Ierusalem, tunc scitote quia appropinquavit desolatio eius:

verses.textEn: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, and those who are in its midst withdraw, and those who are in the countryside not enter into it.
verses.textLa: tunc qui in Iudæa sunt, fugiant ad montes: et qui in medio eius, discedant: et qui in regionibus, non intrent in eam.

verses.textEn: For these are the days of retribution, so that all things may be fulfilled, which have been written.
verses.textLa: Quia dies ultionis hi sunt, ut impleantur omnia, quæ scripta sunt.

verses.textEn: Then woe to those who are pregnant or nursing in those days. For there will be great distress upon the land and great wrath upon this people.
verses.textLa: Væ autem prægnantibus, et nutrientibus in illis diebus. Erit enim pressura magna super terram, et ira populo huic.

verses.textEn: And they will fall by the edge of the sword. And they will be led away as captives into all nations. And Jerusalem will be trampled by the Gentiles, until the times of the nations are fulfilled.
verses.textLa: Et cadent in ore gladii: et captivi ducentur in omnes Gentes. Et Ierusalem calcabitur a Gentibus: donec impleantur tempora nationum.

verses.textEn: And there will be signs in the sun and the moon and the stars. And there will be, on earth, distress among the Gentiles, out of confusion at the roaring of the sea and of the waves:
verses.textLa: Et erunt signa in sole, et luna, et stellis, et in terris pressura Gentium præ confusione sonitus maris, et fluctuum:

verses.textEn: men withering away out of fear and out of apprehension over the things that will overwhelm the whole world. For the powers of the heavens will be moved.
verses.textLa: arescentibus hominibus præ timore, et expectatione, quæ supervenient universo orbi: nam virtutes cælorum movebuntur:

verses.textEn: And then they will see the Son of man coming on a cloud, with great power and majesty.
verses.textLa: et tunc videbunt Filium hominis venientem in nube cum potestate magna, et maiestate.
verses.notes: This verse plainly teaches that Jesus Christ will return, bodily, at the end of the tribulation. Jesus will return bodily, for a brief time, to establish His kingdom on earth. He does not remain on earth for long, because He must reign over the earth from Heaven. So He returns to Heaven to await the day of Judgment.

verses.textEn: But when these things begin to happen, lift up your heads and look around you, because your redemption draws near.”
verses.textLa: His autem fieri incipientibus, respicite, et levate capita vestra: quoniam appropinquat redemptio vestra.

verses.textEn: And he told them a comparison: “Take notice of the fig tree and of all the trees.
verses.textLa: Et dixit illis similitudinem: Videte ficulneam, et omnes arbores:

verses.textEn: When presently they produce fruit from themselves, you know that summer is near.
verses.textLa: cum producunt iam ex se fructum, scitis quoniam prope est æstas.

verses.textEn: So you also, when you will have seen these things happen, know that the kingdom of God is near.
verses.textLa: Ita et vos cum videritis hæc fieri, scitote quoniam prope est regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: Amen I say to you, this lineage shall not pass away, until all these things happen.
verses.textLa: Amen dico vobis, quia non præteribit generatio hæc, donec omnia fiant.

verses.textEn: Heaven and earth shall pass away. But my words shall not pass away.
verses.textLa: Cælum, et terra transibunt: verba autem mea non transibunt.

verses.textEn: But be attentive to yourselves, lest perhaps your hearts may be weighed down by self-indulgence and inebriation and the cares of this life. And then that day may overwhelm you suddenly.
verses.textLa: Attendite autem vobis, ne forte graventur corda vestra in crapula, et ebrietate, et curis huius vitæ: et superveniat in vos repentina dies illa:

verses.textEn: For like a snare it will overwhelm all those who sit upon the face of the entire earth.
verses.textLa: tamquam laqueus enim superveniet in omnes, qui sedent super faciem omnis terræ.

verses.textEn: And so, be vigilant, praying at all times, so that you may be held worthy to escape from all these things, which are in the future, and to stand before the Son of man.”
verses.textLa: Vigilate itaque, omni tempore orantes, ut digni habeamini fugere ista omnia, quæ futura sunt, et stare ante Filium hominis.

verses.textEn: Now in the daytime, he was teaching in the temple. But truly, departing in the evening, he lodged on the mount that is called Olivet.
verses.textLa: Erat autem diebus docens in templo: noctibus vero exiens, morabatur in monte, qui vocatur Oliveti.

verses.textEn: And all the people arrived in the morning to listen to him in the temple.
verses.textLa: Et omnis populus manicabat ad eum in templo audire eum.

verses.textEn: Now the days of the Feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called Passover, were approaching.
verses.textLa: Appropinquabat autem dies festus Azymorum, qui dicitur Pascha:

verses.textEn: And the leaders of the priests, and the scribes, were seeking a way to execute Jesus. Yet truly, they were afraid of the people.
verses.textLa: et quærebant principes sacerdotum, et scribæ, quomodo Iesum interficerent: timebant vero plebem.

verses.textEn: Then Satan entered into Judas, who was surnamed Iscariot, one of the twelve.
verses.textLa: Intravit autem satanas in Iudam, qui cognominabatur Iscariotes, unum de duodecim.

verses.textEn: And he went out and was speaking with the leaders of the priests, and the magistrates, as to how he might hand him over to them.
verses.textLa: Et abiit, et locutus est cum principibus sacerdotum, et magistratibus, quemadmodum illum traderet eis.

verses.textEn: And they were glad, and so they made an agreement to give him money.
verses.textLa: Et gavisi sunt, et pacti sunt pecuniam illi dare.

verses.textEn: And he made a promise. And he was seeking an opportunity to hand him over, apart from the crowds.
verses.textLa: Et spopondit. Et quærebat opportunitatem ut traderet illum sine turbis.

verses.textEn: Then the day of Unleavened Bread arrived, on which it was necessary to kill the Pascal lamb.
verses.textLa: Venit autem dies Azymorum, in qua necesse erat occidi Pascha.

verses.textEn: And he sent Peter and John, saying, “Go out, and prepare the Passover for us, so that we may eat.”
verses.textLa: Et misit Petrum, et Ioannem, dicens: Euntes parate nobis pascha, ut manducemus.

verses.textEn: But they said, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Ubi vis paremus?

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Behold, as you are entering into the city, a certain man will meet you, carrying a pitcher of water. Follow him to the house into which he enters.
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad eos: Ecce introeuntibus vobis in civitatem, occurret vobis homo quidam amphoram aquæ portans: sequimini eum in domum, in quam intrat,

verses.textEn: And you shall say to the father of the household: ‘The Teacher says to you: Where is the guestroom, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?’
verses.textLa: et dicetis patrifamilias domus: Dicit tibi Magister: Ubi est diversorium, ubi Pascha cum discipulis meis manducem?

verses.textEn: And he will show you a large cenacle, fully furnished. And so, prepare it there.”
verses.textLa: Et ipse ostendet vobis cœnaculum magnum stratum, et ibi parate.

verses.textEn: And going out, they found it to be just as he had told them. And they prepared the Passover.
verses.textLa: Euntes autem invenerunt sicut dixit illis, et paraverunt Pascha.

verses.textEn: And when the hour had arrived, he sat down at table, and the twelve Apostles with him.
verses.textLa: Et cum facta esset hora, discubuit, et duodecim Apostoli cum eo.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “With longing have I desired to eat this Passover with you, before I suffer.
verses.textLa: et ait illis: Desiderio desideravi hoc Pascha manducare vobiscum, antequam patiar.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, that from this time, I will not eat it, until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.”
verses.textLa: Dico enim vobis, quia ex hoc non manducabo illud, donec impleatur in regno Dei.

verses.textEn: And having taken the chalice, he gave thanks, and he said: “Take this and share it among yourselves.
verses.textLa: Et accepto calice gratias egit, et dixit: Accipite, et dividite inter vos.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, that I will not drink from the fruit of the vine, until the kingdom of God arrives.”
verses.textLa: dico enim vobis quod non bibam de generatione vitis, donec regnum Dei veniat.

verses.textEn: And taking bread, he gave thanks and broke it and gave it to them, saying: “This is my body, which is given for you. Do this as a commemoration of me.”
verses.textLa: Et accepto pane gratias egit, et fregit, et dedit eis, dicens: Hoc est corpus meum, quod pro vobis datur: hoc facite in meam commemorationem.

verses.textEn: Similarly also, he took the chalice, after he had eaten the meal, saying: “This chalice is the new covenant in my blood, which will be shed for you.
verses.textLa: Similiter et calicem, postquam cœnavit, dicens: Hic est calix novum testamentum in sanguine meo, qui pro vobis fundetur.

verses.textEn: But in truth, behold, the hand of my betrayer is with me at table.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen ecce manus tradentis me, mecum est in mensa.

verses.textEn: And indeed, the Son of man goes according to what has been determined. And yet, woe to that man by whom he will be betrayed.”
verses.textLa: Et quidem Filius hominis, secundum quod definitum est, vadit: verumtamen væ homini illi, per quem tradetur.

verses.textEn: And they began to inquire among themselves, as to which of them might do this.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi cœperunt quærere inter se, quis esset ex eis, qui hoc facturus esset.

verses.textEn: Now there was also a contention among them, as to which of them seemed to be the greater.
verses.textLa: Facta est autem et contentio inter eos, quis eorum videretur esse maior.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “The kings of the Gentiles dominate them; and those who hold authority over them are called beneficent.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem eis: Reges Gentium dominantur eorum: et qui potestatem habent super eos, benefici vocantur.

verses.textEn: But it must not be so with you. Instead, whoever is greater among you, let him become the lesser. And whoever is the leader, let him become the server.
verses.textLa: Vos autem non sic: sed qui maior est in vobis, fiat sicut minor: et qui præcessor est, sicut ministrator.

verses.textEn: For who is greater: he who sits at table, or he who serves? Is not he who sits at table? Yet I am in your midst as one who serves.
verses.textLa: Nam quis maior est, qui recumbit, an qui ministrat? Nonne qui recumbit? Ego autem in medio vestrum sum, sicut qui ministrat:

verses.textEn: But you are those who have remained with me during my trials.
verses.textLa: vos autem estis, qui permansistis mecum in tentationibus meis:

verses.textEn: And I dispose to you, just as my Father has disposed to me, a kingdom,
verses.textLa: Et ego dispono vobis sicut disposuit mihi Pater meus regnum,

verses.textEn: so that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and so that you may sit upon thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.”
verses.textLa: ut edatis, et bibatis super mensam meam in regno meo: et sedeatis super thronos iudicantes duodecim tribus Israel.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said: “Simon, Simon! Behold, Satan has asked for you, so that he may sift you like wheat.
verses.textLa: Ait autem Dominus: Simon, Simon, ecce satanas expetivit vos ut cribraret sicut triticum:

verses.textEn: But I have prayed for you, so that your faith may not fail, and so that you, once converted, may confirm your brothers.”
verses.textLa: ego autem rogavi pro te ut non deficiat fides tua: et tu aliquando conversus confirma fratres tuos.

verses.textEn: And he said to him, “Lord, I am prepared to go with you, even to prison and to death.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit ei: Domine, tecum paratus sum et in carcerem, et in mortem ire.

verses.textEn: And he said, “I say to you, Peter, the rooster will not crow this day, until you have three times denied that you know me.” And he said to them,
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Dico tibi Petre, non cantabit hodie gallus, donec ter abneges nosse me. Et dixit eis:

verses.textEn: “When I sent you without money or provisions or shoes, did you lack anything?”
verses.textLa: Quando misi vos sine sacculo, et pera, et calceamentis, numquid aliquid defuit vobis?
verses.notes: The word ‘sacculo’ refers to a small bag for carrying money, and the word ‘pera’ refers to a larger bag for carrying provisions. The translation is according to what is in each type of bag, for that is what they were prohibited from carrying.

verses.textEn: And they said, “Nothing.” Then he said to them: “But now, let whoever has money take it, and likewise with provisions. And whoever does not have these, let him sell his coat and buy a sword.
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Nihil. Dixit ergo eis: Sed nunc qui habet sacculum, tollat similiter et peram: et qui non habet, vendat tunicam suam, et emat gladium.

verses.textEn: For I say to you, that what has been written must still be fulfilled in me: ‘And he was esteemed with the wicked.’ Yet even these things about me have an end.”
verses.textLa: Dico enim vobis, quoniam adhuc hoc, quod scriptum est, oportet impleri in me: Et cum iniquis deputatus est. Etenim ea, quæ sunt de me, finem habent.
verses.notes: These things written about Christ are also about the future of the Church. The Church will be esteemed with the wicked; the true Faith will be outlawed. Yet even these things will have an end.

verses.textEn: So they said, “Lord, behold, there are two swords here.” But he said to them, “It is sufficient.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Domine, ecce duo gladii hic. At ille dixit eis: Satis est.

verses.textEn: And departing, he went out, according to his custom, to the Mount of Olives. And his disciples also followed him.
verses.textLa: Et egressus ibat secundum consuetudinem in Monte Olivarum. Secuti sunt autem illum et discipuli.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the place, he said to them: “Pray, lest you enter into temptation.”
verses.textLa: Et cum pervenisset ad locum, dixit illis: Orate ne intretis in tentationem.

verses.textEn: And he was separated from them by about a stone’s throw. And kneeling down, he prayed,
verses.textLa: Et ipse avulsus est ab eis quantum iactus est lapidis: et positis genibus orabat,

verses.textEn: saying: “Father, if you are willing, take this chalice away from me. Yet truly, let not my will, but yours, be done.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Pater si vis, transfer calicem istum a me: Verumtamen non mea voluntas, sed tua fiat.

verses.textEn: Then an Angel appeared to him from heaven, strengthening him. And being in agony, he prayed more intensely;
verses.textLa: Apparuit autem illi Angelus de cælo, confortans eum. Et factus in agonia, prolixius orabat.

verses.textEn: and so his sweat became like drops of blood, running down to the ground.
verses.textLa: Et factus est sudor eius, sicut guttæ sanguinis decurrentis in terram.

verses.textEn: And when he had risen up from prayer and had gone to his disciples, he found them sleeping out of sorrow.
verses.textLa: Et cum surrexisset ab oratione, et venisset ad discipulos suos, invenit eos dormientes præ tristitia.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Why are you sleeping? Rise up, pray, lest you enter into temptation.”
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Quid dormitis? surgite, orate, ne intretis in tentationem.

verses.textEn: While he was still speaking, behold, a crowd arrived. And he who is called Judas, one of the twelve, went ahead of them and approached Jesus, in order to kiss him.
verses.textLa: Adhuc eo loquente ecce turba: et qui vocabatur Iudas, unus de duodecim, antecedebat eos: et appropinquavit Iesu ut oscularetur eum.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to him, “Judas, do you betray the Son of man with a kiss?”
verses.textLa: Iesus autem dixit illi: Iuda, osculo Filium hominis tradis?

verses.textEn: Then those who were around him, realizing what was about to happen, said to him: “Lord, shall we strike with the sword?”
verses.textLa: Videntes autem hi, qui circa ipsum erant, quod futurum erat, dixerunt ei: Domine, si percutimus in gladio?

verses.textEn: And one of them struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his right ear.
verses.textLa: Et percussit unus ex illis servum principis sacerdotum, et amputavit auriculam eius dexteram.

verses.textEn: But in response, Jesus said, “Permit even this.” And when he had touched his ear, he healed him.
verses.textLa: Respondens autem Iesus, ait: Sinite usque huc. Et cum tetigisset auriculam eius, sanavit eum.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said to the leaders of the priests, and the magistrates of the temple, and the elders, who had come to him: “Have you gone out, as if against a thief, with swords and clubs?
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Iesus ad eos, qui venerant ad se, principes sacerdotum, et magistratus templi, et seniores: Quasi ad latronem existis cum gladiis, et fustibus?

verses.textEn: When I was with you each day in the temple, you did not extend your hands against me. But this is your hour and that of the power of darkness.”
verses.textLa: Cum quotidie vobiscum fuerim in templo, non extendistis manus in me: sed hæc est hora vestra, et potestas tenebrarum.

verses.textEn: And apprehending him, they led him to the house of the high priest. Yet truly, Peter followed at a distance.
verses.textLa: Comprehendentes autem eum, duxerunt ad domum principis sacerdotum: Petrus vero sequebatur a longe.

verses.textEn: Now as they were sitting around a fire, which had been kindled in the middle of the atrium, Peter was in their midst.
verses.textLa: Accenso autem igne in medio atrii, et circumsedentibus illis, erat Petrus in medio eorum.

verses.textEn: And when a certain woman servant had seen him sitting in its light, and had looked at him intently, she said, “This one was also with him.”
verses.textLa: Quem cum vidisset ancilla quædam sedentem ad lumen, et eum fuisset intuita, dixit: Et hic cum illo erat.

verses.textEn: But he denied him by saying, “Woman, I do not know him.”
verses.textLa: At ille negavit eum, dicens: Mulier, non novi illum.

verses.textEn: And after a little while, another one, seeing him, said, “You also are one of them.” Yet Peter said, “O man, I am not.”
verses.textLa: Et post pusillum alius videns eum, dixit: Et tu de illis es. Petrus vero ait: O homo, non sum.

verses.textEn: And after the interval of about one hour had passed, someone else affirmed it, saying: “Truly, this one also was with him. For he is also a Galilean.”
verses.textLa: Et intervallo facto quasi horæ unius, alius quidam affirmabat, dicens: Vere et hic cum illo erat: nam et Galilæus est.

verses.textEn: And Peter said: “Man, I do not know what you are saying.” And at once, while he was still speaking, the rooster crowed.
verses.textLa: Et ait Petrus: Homo, nescio quid dicis. Et continuo adhuc illo loquente cantavit gallus.

verses.textEn: And the Lord turned around and looked at Peter. And Peter remembered the word of the Lord that he had said: “For before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times.”
verses.textLa: Et conversus Dominus respexit Petrum. Et recordatus est Petrus verbi Domini, sicut dixerat: Quia priusquam gallus cantet, ter me negabis.

verses.textEn: And going out, Peter wept bitterly.
verses.textLa: Et egressus foras Petrus flevit amare.

verses.textEn: And the men who were holding him ridiculed him and beat him.
verses.textLa: Et viri, qui tenebant illum, illudebant ei, cædentes.

verses.textEn: And they blindfolded him and repeatedly struck his face. And they questioned him, saying: “Prophesy! Who is it that struck you?”
verses.textLa: Et velaverunt eum, et percutiebant faciem eius: et interrogabant eum, dicentes: Prophetiza, quis est, qui te percussit?

verses.textEn: And blaspheming in many other ways, they spoke against him.
verses.textLa: Et alia multa blasphemantes dicebant in eum.

verses.textEn: And when it was daytime, the elders of the people, and the leaders of the priests, and the scribes convened. And they led him into their council, saying, “If you are the Christ, tell us.”
verses.textLa: Et ut factus est dies, convenerunt seniores plebis, et principes sacerdotum, et scribæ, et duxerunt illum in concilium suum, dicentes: Si tu es Christus, dic nobis.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “If I tell you, you will not believe me.
verses.textLa: Et ait illis: Si vobis dixero, non credetis mihi:

verses.textEn: And if I also question you, you will not answer me. Neither will you release me.
verses.textLa: si autem et interrogavero, non respondebitis mihi, neque dimittetis.

verses.textEn: But from this time, the Son of man will be sitting at the right hand of the power of God.”
verses.textLa: Ex hoc autem erit Filius hominis sedens a dextris virtutis Dei.

verses.textEn: Then they all said, “So you are the Son of God?” And he said. “You are saying that I am.”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt autem omnes: Tu ergo es Filius Dei? Qui ait: Vos dicitis, quia ego sum.

verses.textEn: And they said: “Why do we still require testimony? For we have heard it ourselves, from his own mouth.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Quid adhuc desideramus testimonium? ipsi enim audivimus de ore eius.

verses.textEn: And the entire multitude of them, rising up, led him to Pilate.
verses.textLa: Et surgens omnis multitudo eorum, duxerunt illum ad Pilatum.

verses.textEn: Then they began to accuse him, saying, “We found this one subverting our nation, and prohibiting giving tribute to Caesar, and saying that he is Christ the king.”
verses.textLa: Cœperunt autem illum accusare, dicentes: Hunc invenimus subvertentem gentem nostram, et prohibentem tributa dare Cæsari, et dicentem se Christum regem esse.

verses.textEn: And Pilate questioned him, saying: “You are the king of the Jews?” But in response, he said: “You are saying it.”
verses.textLa: Pilatus autem interrogavit eum, dicens: Tu es rex Iudæorum? At ille respondens ait: Tu dicis.

verses.textEn: Then Pilate said to the leaders of the priests and to the crowds, “I find no case against this man.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem Pilatus ad principes sacerdotum, et turbas: Nihil invenio causæ in hoc homine.

verses.textEn: But they continued more intensely, saying: “He has stirred up the people, teaching throughout all of Judea, beginning from Galilee, even to this place.”
verses.textLa: At illi invalescebant, dicentes: Commovet populum docens per universam Iudæam, incipiens a Galilæa usque huc.

verses.textEn: But Pilate, upon hearing Galilee, asked if the man were of Galilee.
verses.textLa: Pilatus autem audiens Galilæam, interrogavit si homo Galilæus esset.

verses.textEn: And when he realized that he was under Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent him away to Herod, who was himself also at Jerusalem in those days.
verses.textLa: Et ut cognovit quod de Herodis potestate esset, remisit eum ad Herodem, qui et ipse Ierosolymis erat illis diebus.

verses.textEn: Then Herod, upon seeing Jesus, was very glad. For he had been wanting to see him for a long time, because he had heard so many things about him, and he was hoping to see some kind of sign wrought by him.
verses.textLa: Herodes autem viso Iesu, gavisus est valde. Erat enim cupiens ex multo tempore videre eum, eo quod audierat multa de eo, et sperabat signum aliquod videre ab eo fieri.

verses.textEn: Then he questioned him with many words. But he gave him no response at all.
verses.textLa: Interrogabat autem eum multis sermonibus. At ipse nihil illi respondebat.

verses.textEn: And the leaders of the priests, and the scribes, stood firm in persistently accusing him.
verses.textLa: Stabant autem principes sacerdotum, et scribæ constanter accusantes eum.
verses.notes: The leaders were of the priests; the scribes had no leaders among them.

verses.textEn: Then Herod, with his soldiers, scorned him. And he ridiculed him, clothing him in a white garment. And he sent him back to Pilate.
verses.textLa: Sprevit autem illum Herodes cum exercitu suo: et illusit indutum veste alba, et remisit ad Pilatum.

verses.textEn: And Herod and Pilate became friends on that day. For previously they were enemies to one another.
verses.textLa: Et facti sunt amici Herodes et Pilatus in ipsa die: nam antea inimici erant ad invicem.

verses.textEn: And Pilate, calling together the leaders of the priests, and the magistrates, and the people,
verses.textLa: Pilatus autem convocatis principibus sacerdotum, et magistratibus, et plebe,

verses.textEn: said to them: “You have brought before me this man, as one who disturbs the people. And behold, having questioned him before you, I find no case against this man, in those things about which you accuse him.
verses.textLa: dixit ad illos: Obtulistis mihi hunc hominem, quasi avertentem populum, et ecce ego coram vobis interrogans, nullam causam inveni in homine isto ex his, in quibus eum accusatis.

verses.textEn: And neither did Herod. For I sent you all to him, and behold, nothing deserving of death was recorded about him.
verses.textLa: Sed neque Herodes: nam remisi vos ad illum, et ecce nihil dignum morte actum est ei.
verses.notes: The word ‘actum,’ in this context, refers to official records. Herod did not record any guilty verdict or judicial decision against him.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I will chastise him and release him.”
verses.textLa: Emendatum ergo illum dimittam.

verses.textEn: Now he was required to release one person for them on the feast day.
verses.textLa: Necesse autem habebat dimittere eis per diem festum, unum.

verses.textEn: But the entire crowd exclaimed together, saying: “Take this one, and release to us Barabbas!”
verses.textLa: Exclamavit autem simul universa turba, dicens: Tolle hunc, et dimitte nobis Barabbam,

verses.textEn: Now he had been cast into prison because of a certain sedition that occurred in the city and for murder.
verses.textLa: qui erat propter seditionem quamdam factam in civitate et homicidium, missus in carcerem.

verses.textEn: Then Pilate spoke to them again, wanting to release Jesus.
verses.textLa: Iterum autem Pilatus locutus est ad eos, volens dimittere Iesum.

verses.textEn: But they shouted in response, saying: “Crucify him! Crucify him!”
verses.textLa: At illi succlamabant, dicentes: Crucifige, crucifige eum.

verses.textEn: Then he said to them a third time: “Why? What evil has he done? I find no case against him for death. Therefore, I will chastise him and release him.”
verses.textLa: Ille autem tertio dixit ad illos: Quid enim mali fecit iste? nullam causam mortis invenio in eo: corripiam ergo illum, et dimittam.

verses.textEn: But they persisted, with loud voices, in demanding that he be crucified. And their voices increased in intensity.
verses.textLa: At illi instabant vocibus magnis postulantes ut crucifigeretur: et invalescebant voces eorum.

verses.textEn: And so Pilate issued a judgment granting their petition.
verses.textLa: Et Pilatus adiudicavit fieri petitionem eorum.

verses.textEn: Then he released for them the one who had been cast into prison for murder and sedition, whom they were requesting. Yet truly, Jesus he handed over to their will.
verses.textLa: Dimisit autem illis eum, qui propter homicidium, et seditionem missus fuerat in carcerem, quem petebant, Iesum vero tradidit voluntati eorum.

verses.textEn: And as they were leading him away, they apprehended a certain one, Simon of Cyrene, as he was returning from the countryside. And they imposed the cross on him to carry after Jesus.
verses.textLa: Et cum ducerent eum, apprehenderunt Simonem quemdam Cyrenensem venientem de villa: et imposuerunt illi crucem portare post Iesum.

verses.textEn: Then a great crowd of people followed him, with women who were mourning and lamenting him.
verses.textLa: Sequebatur autem illum multa turba populi, et mulierum: quæ plangebant, et lamentabantur eum.

verses.textEn: But Jesus, turning to them, said: “Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep over me. Instead, weep over yourselves and over your children.
verses.textLa: Conversus autem ad illas Iesus, dixit: Filiæ Ierusalem, nolite flere super me, sed super vos ipsas flete, et super filios vestros.

verses.textEn: For behold, the days will arrive in which they will say, ‘Blessed are the barren, and the wombs that have not borne, and the breasts that have not nursed.’
verses.textLa: Quoniam ecce venient dies, in quibus dicent: Beatæ steriles, et ventres, qui non genuerunt, et ubera, quæ non lactaverunt.

verses.textEn: Then they will begin to say to the mountains, ‘Fall over us,’ and to the hills, ‘Cover us.’
verses.textLa: Tunc incipient dicere montibus: Cadite super nos: et collibus: Operite nos.

verses.textEn: For if they do these things with green wood, what will be done with the dry?”
verses.textLa: Quia si in viridi ligno hæc faciunt, in arido quid fiet?

verses.textEn: Now they also led out two other criminals with him, in order to execute them.
verses.textLa: Ducebantur autem et alii duo nequam cum eo, ut interficerentur.

verses.textEn: And when they arrived at the place that is called Calvary, they crucified him there, with the robbers, one to the right and the other to the left.
verses.textLa: Et postquam venerunt in locum, qui vocatur Calvariæ, ibi crucifixerunt eum: et latrones, unum a dextris, et alterum a sinistris.

verses.textEn: Then Jesus said, “Father, forgive them. For they know not what they do.” And truly, dividing his garments, they cast lots.
verses.textLa: Iesus autem dicebat: Pater, dimitte illis: non enim sciunt quid faciunt. Dividentes vero vestimenta eius, miserunt sortes.

verses.textEn: And people were standing near, watching. And the leaders among them derided him, saying: “He saved others. Let him save himself, if this one is the Christ, the elect of God.”
verses.textLa: Et stabat populus spectans, et deridebant eum principes cum eis, dicentes: Alios salvos fecit, se salvum faciat, si hic est Christus Dei electus.

verses.textEn: And the soldiers also ridiculed him, approaching him and offering him vinegar,
verses.textLa: Illudebant autem ei et milites accedentes, et acetum offerentes ei,

verses.textEn: and saying, “If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself.”
verses.textLa: et dicentes: Si tu es rex Iudæorum, salvum te fac.

verses.textEn: Now there was also an inscription written over him in letters of Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew: THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
verses.textLa: Erat autem et superscriptio scripta super eum litteris Græcis, et Latinis, et Hebraicis: Hic est rex Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: And one of those robbers who were hanging blasphemed him, saying, “If you are the Christ, save yourself and us.”
verses.textLa: Unus autem de his, qui pendebant, latronibus, blasphemabat eum, dicens: Si tu es Christus, salvum fac temetipsum, et nos.

verses.textEn: But the other responded by rebuking him, saying: “Do you have no fear of God, since you are under the same condemnation?
verses.textLa: Respondens autem alter increpabat eum, dicens: Neque tu times Deum, quod in eadem damnatione es.

verses.textEn: And indeed, it is just for us. For we are receiving what our deeds deserve. But truly, this one has done nothing wrong.”
verses.textLa: Et nos quidem iuste, nam digna factis recipimus: hic vero nihil mali gessit.

verses.textEn: And he said to Jesus, “Lord, remember me when you come into your kingdom.”
verses.textLa: Et dicebat ad Iesum: Domine, memento mei, cum veneris in regnum tuum.

verses.textEn: And Jesus said to him, “Amen I say to you, this day you shall be with me in Paradise.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit illi Iesus: Amen dico tibi: Hodie mecum eris in Paradiso.

verses.textEn: Now it was nearly the sixth hour, and a darkness occurred over the entire earth, until the ninth hour.
verses.textLa: Erat autem fere hora sexta, et tenebræ factæ sunt in universam terram usque ad horam nonam.

verses.textEn: And the sun was obscured. And the veil of the temple was torn down the middle.
verses.textLa: Et obscuratus est sol: et velum templi scissum est medium.

verses.textEn: And Jesus, crying out with a loud voice, said: “Father, into your hands I commend my spirit.” And upon saying this, he expired.
verses.textLa: Et clamans voce magna Iesus ait: Pater in manus tuas commendo spiritum meum. Et hæc dicens, expiravit.

verses.textEn: Now, the centurion, seeing what had happened, glorified God, saying, “Truly, this man was the Just One.”
verses.textLa: Videns autem Centurio quod factum fuerat, glorificavit Deum, dicens: Vere hic homo iustus erat.
verses.notes: We know from the Gospel of Mark that the centurion was not merely saying that Jesus was a good man or a just man, but the Son of God. Some might argue that the centurion lacked true faith, and was merely remarking on Jesus’ innocence, that he was just, but not the Son of God. But the Romans believed in gods and sons of gods, so the centurion had a basic understanding that God can have a Son. And a Roman soldier stationed in Judea would certainly be aware of the controversies among the inhabitants. So he knew that many believed in Jesus as the Son of God, and he also knew that this was the controversy over which he was killed. Then, knowing all this, upon seeing the very act of Christ dying for our salvation, which effects the salvation of all, his comment was not merely that Jesus was innocent. For Christ was only innocent of the charges, if He is the Son of God and the Just One. If Jesus were merely a just man, or a son of God as all men are sons of God, then He would not be innocent. Therefore, the Soldier was saying that this man Jesus was truly the Son of God, the Just One.

verses.textEn: And the entire crowd of those who came together to see this spectacle also saw what had happened, and they returned, striking their breasts.
verses.textLa: Et omnis turba eorum, qui simul aderant ad spectaculum istud, et videbant quæ fiebant, percutientes pectora sua revertebantur.

verses.textEn: Now all those who knew him, and the women who had followed him from Galilee, were standing at a distance, watching these things.
verses.textLa: Stabant autem omnes noti eius a longe: et mulieres, quæ secutæ eum erant a Galilæa, hæc videntes.

verses.textEn: And behold, there was a man named Joseph, who was a councilman, a good and just man,
verses.textLa: Et ecce vir nomine Ioseph, qui erat decurio, vir bonus, et iustus:

verses.textEn: (for he had not consented to their decision or their actions). He was from Arimathea, a city of Judea. And he was himself also anticipating the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: hic non consenserat consilio, et actibus eorum, ab Arimathæa civitate Iudææ, qui expectabat et ipse regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: This man approached Pilate and petitioned for the body of Jesus.
verses.textLa: Hic accessit ad Pilatum, et petiit corpus Iesu:

verses.textEn: And taking him down, he wrapped him in a fine linen cloth, and he placed him in a tomb hewn from rock, in which no one had ever been placed.
verses.textLa: et depositum involvit sindone, et posuit eum in monumento exciso, in quo nondum quisquam positus fuerat.

verses.textEn: And it was the day of Preparation, and the Sabbath was drawing near.
verses.textLa: Et dies erat Parasceves, et Sabbatum illucescebat.

verses.textEn: Now the women who had come with him from Galilee, by following, saw the tomb and the manner in which his body was placed.
verses.textLa: Subsecutæ autem mulieres, quæ cum eo venerant de Galilæa, viderunt monumentum, et quemadmodum positum erat corpus eius.

verses.textEn: And upon returning, they prepared aromatic spices and ointments. But on the Sabbath, indeed, they rested, according to the commandment.
verses.textLa: Et revertentes paraverunt aromata, et unguenta: et Sabbato quidem siluerunt secundum mandatum.

verses.textEn: Then, on the first Sabbath, at very first light, they went to the tomb, carrying the aromatic spices that they had prepared.
verses.textLa: Una autem Sabbati valde diluculo venerunt ad monumentum, portantes quæ paraverant, aromata:

verses.textEn: And they found the stone rolled back from the tomb.
verses.textLa: et invenerunt lapidem revolutum a monumento.

verses.textEn: And upon entering, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
verses.textLa: Et ingressæ non invenerunt corpus Domini Iesu.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while their minds were still confused about this, behold, two men stood beside them, in shining apparel.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, dum mente consternatæ essent de isto, ecce duo viri steterunt secus illas in veste fulgenti.

verses.textEn: Then, since they were afraid and were turning their faces toward the ground, these two said to them: “Why do you seek the living with the dead?
verses.textLa: Cum timerent autem, et declinarent vultum in terram, dixerunt ad illas: Quid quæritis viventem cum mortuis?

verses.textEn: He is not here, for he has risen. Recall how he spoke to you, when he was still in Galilee,
verses.textLa: non est hic, sed surrexit: recordamini qualiter locutus est vobis, cum adhuc in Galilæa esset,

verses.textEn: saying: ‘For the Son of man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and on the third day rise again.’ ”
verses.textLa: dicens: Quia oportet Filium hominis tradi in manus hominum peccatorum, et crucifigi, et die tertia resurgere.

verses.textEn: And they called to mind his words.
verses.textLa: Et recordatæ sunt verborum eius.

verses.textEn: And returning from the tomb, they reported all these things to the eleven, and to all the others.
verses.textLa: Et regressæ a monumento nunciaverunt hæc omnia illis undecim, et ceteris omnibus.

verses.textEn: Now it was Mary Magdalene, and Joanna, and Mary of James, and the other women who were with them, who told these things to the Apostles.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Maria Magdalene, et Ioanna, et Maria Iacobi, et ceteræ, quæ cum eis erant, quæ dicebant ad Apostolos hæc.

verses.textEn: But these words seemed to them a delusion. And so they did not believe them.
verses.textLa: Et visa sunt ante illos, sicut deliramentum verba ista: et non crediderunt illis.

verses.textEn: But Peter, rising up, ran to the tomb. And stooping down, he saw the linen cloths positioned alone, and he went away wondering to himself about what had happened.
verses.textLa: Petrus autem surgens cucurrit ad monumentum: et procumbens vidit linteamina sola posita, et abiit secum mirans quod factum fuerat.

verses.textEn: And behold, two of them went out, on the same day, to a town named Emmaus, which was the distance of sixty stadia from Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et ecce duo ex illis ibant ipsa die in castellum, quod erat in spatio stadiorum sexaginta ab Ierusalem, nomine Emmaus.

verses.textEn: And they spoke to one another about all of these things that had occurred.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi loquebantur ad invicem de his omnibus, quæ acciderant.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while they were speculating and questioning within themselves, Jesus himself, drawing near, traveled with them.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, dum fabularentur, et secum quærerent: et ipse Iesus appropinquans ibat cum illis:

verses.textEn: But their eyes were restrained, so that they would not recognize him.
verses.textLa: oculi autem illorum tenebantur ne eum agnoscerent.

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “What are these words, which you are discussing with one another, as you walk and are sad?”
verses.textLa: Et ait ad illos: Qui sunt hi sermones, quos confertis ad invicem ambulantes, et estis tristes?

verses.textEn: And one of them, whose name was Cleopas, responded by saying to him, “Are you the only one visiting Jerusalem who does not know the things that have happened there in these days?”
verses.textLa: Et respondens unus, cui nomen Cleophas, dixit ei: Tu solus peregrinus es in Ierusalem, et non cognovisti quæ facta sunt in illa his diebus?

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “What things?” And they said, “About Jesus of Nazareth, who was a noble prophet, powerful in works and in words, before God and all the people.
verses.textLa: Quibus ille dixit: Quæ? Et dixerunt: De Iesu Nazareno, qui fuit vir propheta, potens in opere, et sermone coram Deo, et omni populo:

verses.textEn: And how our high priests and leaders handed him over to be condemned to death. And they crucified him.
verses.textLa: Et quomodo eum tradiderunt summi sacerdotes, et principes nostri in damnationem mortis, et crucifixerunt eum.

verses.textEn: But we were hoping that he would be the Redeemer of Israel. And now, on top of all this, today is the third day since these things have happened.
verses.textLa: Nos autem sperabamus quia ipse esset redempturus Israel: et nunc super hæc omnia, tertia dies est hodie quod hæc facta sunt.

verses.textEn: Then, too, certain women from among us terrified us. For before daytime, they were at the tomb,
verses.textLa: Sed et mulieres quædam ex nostris terruerunt nos, quæ ante lucem fuerunt ad monumentum,

verses.textEn: and, having not found his body, they returned, saying that they had even seen a vision of Angels, who said that he is alive.
verses.textLa: et, non invento corpore eius, venerunt, dicentes se etiam visionem Angelorum vidisse, qui dicunt eum vivere.

verses.textEn: And some of us went out to the tomb. And they found it just as the women had said. But truly, they did not find him.”
verses.textLa: Et abierunt quidam ex nostris ad monumentum: et ita invenerunt sicut mulieres dixerunt, ipsum vero non invenerunt.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “How foolish and reluctant in heart you are, to believe everything that has been spoken by the Prophets!
verses.textLa: Et ipse dixit ad eos: O stulti, et tardi corde ad credendum in omnibus, quæ locuti sunt Prophetæ!

verses.textEn: Was not the Christ required to suffer these things, and so enter into his glory?”
verses.textLa: Nonne hæc oportuit pati Christum, et ita intrare in gloriam suam?

verses.textEn: And beginning from Moses and all the Prophets, he interpreted for them, in all the Scriptures, the things that were about him.
verses.textLa: Et incipiens a Moyse, et omnibus Prophetis, interpretabatur illis in omnibus scripturis, quæ de ipso erant.

verses.textEn: And they drew near to the town where they were going. And he conducted himself so as to go on further.
verses.textLa: Et appropinquaverunt castello quo ibant: et ipse se finxit longius ire.

verses.textEn: But they were insistent with him, saying, “Remain with us, because it is toward evening and now daylight is declining.” And so he entered with them.
verses.textLa: Et coegerunt illum, dicentes: Mane nobiscum, quoniam advesperascit, et inclinata est iam dies. Et intravit cum illis.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while he was at table with them, he took bread, and he blessed and broke it, and he extended it to them.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, dum recumberet cum eis, accepit panem, et benedixit, ac fregit, et porrigebat illis.

verses.textEn: And their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And he vanished from their eyes.
verses.textLa: Et aperti sunt oculi eorum, et cognoverunt eum: et ipse evanuit ex oculis eorum.

verses.textEn: And they said to one another, “Was not our heart burning within us, while he was speaking on the way, and when he opened the Scriptures to us?”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt ad invicem: Nonne cor nostrum ardens erat in nobis dum loqueretur in via, et aperiret nobis Scripturas?

verses.textEn: And rising up at that same hour, they returned to Jerusalem. And they found the eleven gathered together, and those who were with them,
verses.textLa: Et surgentes eadem hora regressi sunt in Ierusalem: et invenerunt congregatos undecim, et eos, qui cum illis erant,

verses.textEn: saying: “In truth, the Lord has risen, and he has appeared to Simon.”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Quod surrexit Dominus vere, et apparuit Simoni.

verses.textEn: And they explained the things that were done on the way, and how they had recognized him at the breaking of the bread.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi narrabant quæ gesta erant in via: et quomodo cognoverunt eum in fractione panis.

verses.textEn: Then, while they were talking about these things, Jesus stood in their midst, And he said to them: “Peace be with you. It is I. Do not be afraid.”
verses.textLa: Dum autem hæc loquuntur, stetit Iesus in medio eorum, et dicit eis: Pax vobis: ego sum, nolite timere.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, they were very disturbed and terrified, supposing that they saw a spirit.
verses.textLa: Conturbati vero, et conterriti, existimabant se spiritum videre.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “Why are you disturbed, and why do these thoughts rise up in your hearts?
verses.textLa: Et dixit eis: Quid turbati estis, et cogitationes ascendunt in corda vestra?

verses.textEn: See my hands and feet, that it is I myself. Look and touch. For a spirit does not have flesh and bones, as you see that I have.”
verses.textLa: Videte manus meas, et pedes, quia ego ipse sum: palpate, et videte: quia spiritus carnem, et ossa non habet, sicut me videtis habere.

verses.textEn: And when he had said this, he showed them his hands and feet.
verses.textLa: Et cum hoc dixisset, ostendit eis manus, et pedes.

verses.textEn: Then, while they were still in disbelief and in wonder out of joy, he said, “Do you have anything here to eat?”
verses.textLa: Adhuc autem illis non credentibus, et mirantibus præ gaudio, dixit: Habetis hic aliquid, quod manducetur?

verses.textEn: And they offered him a piece of roasted fish and a honeycomb.
verses.textLa: At illi obtulerunt ei partem piscis assi, et favum mellis.

verses.textEn: And when he had eaten these in their sight, taking up what was left, he gave it to them.
verses.textLa: Et cum manducasset coram eis, sumens reliquias dedit eis.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “These are the words that I spoke to you when I was still with you, because all things must be fulfilled which are written in the law of Moses, and in the Prophets, and in the Psalms about me.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad eos: Hæc sunt verba, quæ locutus sum ad vos, cum adhuc essem vobiscum, quoniam necesse est impleri omnia, quæ scripta sunt in lege Moysi, et Prophetis, et Psalmis de me.

verses.textEn: Then he opened their mind, so that they might understand the Scriptures.
verses.textLa: Tunc aperuit illis sensum ut intelligerent Scripturas.

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “For so it is written, and so it was necessary, for the Christ to suffer and to rise up from the dead on the third day,
verses.textLa: Et dixit eis: Quoniam sic scriptum est, et sic oportebat Christum pati, et resurgere a mortuis tertia die:

verses.textEn: and, in his name, for repentance and the remission of sins to be preached, among all the nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: et prædicari in nomine eius pœnitentiam, et remissionem peccatorum in omnes gentes, incipientibus ab Ierosolyma.

verses.textEn: And you are witnesses of these things.
verses.textLa: Vos autem testes estis horum.

verses.textEn: And I am sending the Promise of my Father upon you. But you must stay in the city, until such time as you are clothed with power from on high.”
verses.textLa: Et ego mitto promissum Patris mei in vos. Vos autem sedete in civitate, quoadusque induamini virtute ex alto.

verses.textEn: Then he led them out as far as Bethania. And lifting up his hands, he blessed them.
verses.textLa: Eduxit autem eos foras in Bethaniam: et elevatis manibus suis benedixit eis.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, while he was blessing them, he withdrew from them, and he was carried up into heaven.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, dum benediceret illis, recessit ab eis, et ferebatur in cælum.

verses.textEn: And worshiping, they returned to Jerusalem with great joy.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi adorantes regressi sunt in Ierusalem cum gaudio magno:

verses.textEn: And they were always in the temple, praising and blessing God. Amen.
verses.textLa: et erant semper in templo, laudantes, et benedicentes Deum. Amen.
